properties.Name: Atlit A
properties.Reference: Radan 1981; Raban, 1985: 33-7
properties.Other cargo: Parker notes Assyrian bronze helmets, Babylonian weights (in the form of swans), furniture and candelabras.
properties.Hull remains: Partly preserved.

properties.Name: Pseira
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeology.org/1001/etc/minoan_shipwreck.html    http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/court_and_social/article7028160.ece
properties.Comments: The first Minoan Shipwreck. Six seasons of exploration, ending in 2009, revealed a narrow trail of pottery about 100 feet long at the northern end of the wreck, according to the US journal Archaeology. This broadened out over an area 65 by 50 feet, and Dr Hadjidaki estimates that the ship itself was between 32 and 50 feet long. It had capsized as it sank, spreading the cargo across the sea-bed. She believes the ship probably looked something like the one shown on a sealstone found on Pseira in 1991, with a beaked prow, high stern, and single mast anchored by ropes. It was probably a coasting vessel, delivering everyday goods to ports along the Cretan shore; whether it used a sails, oars or both is not known. More than 200 pottery vessels have been recovered, about 80 of which are complete enough to be identifiable as amphorae and large jars, used for shipping liquids such as wine and olive oil. Philip Betancourt has dated all the vessels to roughly 1800-1675BC, and the clay from which they were made suggests that the ship took on cargo at two or more locations in eastern Crete.
properties.Other cargo: Ceramics including jugs, cups and cooking pots.

properties.Name: Ulu Burun
properties.Reference: R. Payton, Anatolian Studies 41 (1991), 99-106; P. Warnock and M. Pendleton, Anatolian Studies 41 (1991), 107-110; C. Haldane, World Archaeology 24 (1993) 348-360;  INA Quarterly 21.4 (1994); M.-H. Gates, AJA 100 ( 1996), 304-306; C. Pulak, IJNA 27 (1998), 188-224; C. Bachhuber, AJA 110 (2006), 345-363
properties.Comments: An 11 year excavation was undertaken by the INA of this Late Bronze Age merchant ship. Its cargo was amazingly varied, luxurious and was worth a considerable fortune. It has thus been suggested that the ship may have been on a diplomatic voyage carrying palatial gifts.
properties.Other cargo: Ten tons of Cypriot copper ingots (354 oxhide ingots and 121 smaller bun- and pillow-shaped ingots). Nearly a ton of tin ingots. Raw ivory (elephant tusk and hippo teeth!) and ivory carvings, a gold goblet, ebony, glass ingots and an assortment of gold jewellery. Huge amount of organic material including fruits, nuts, spices and other plants. Bronze tools and weapons Cypriot pottery.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Cooking ware, tools, weapons and over 130 pan-balance weights (2 pans were found in a wooden case); saucer lamps, cylinder seals; amber beads and at least 200 flattened blue faience beads. A pair of  intricate wooden (boxwood) writing-boards set with ivory hinges from the Near East.
properties.Ship equipment: 24 anchors

properties.Name: Cape Gelidonya A
properties.Reference: Master Seafarers: the Phoenicians and the Greeks (Periplus, 2004), 26-33, incl. illustrations and site plan;         http://www.inadiscover.com/projects/all/southern_europe_mediterranean_aegean/cape_gelidonya_turkey/introduction/
properties.Comments: Originally discovered in 1958 and re-examined in 1994, this is the oldest shipwreck ever found! A Cypriot cargo of copper ingots and scrap bronze, although the personal possessions of the crew suggest a Canaanite origin.
properties.Other cargo: 34 flat four-handled copper ingots (25kg each) cast in the shape of an ox hide, several tin ingots, several raw bronze ingots and broken bronze tools (scrap axes, adzes, knives and a spade carried in wicker baskets)) destined to be melted down for re-use.
properties.Hull remains: Little remains of the hull, although there is enough to show mortise and tenon construction. Brushwood dunnage still lay in the bottom of the ship's hold.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A set of smith's tools including a small anvil, hammers, a whetstone, stones to polish metals and a bronze block pierced with holes to make metal thread, suggesting that a smith was sailing on the ship. Other possessions include a lamp and a pair of stone mortars made in Syria, as were 4 scarabs and a cylinder seal. There were also nearly 60 graduated stone weights of Near Eastern origin, including Egyptian qedets and Syrian and Canaanite nesefs and shekels. A bronze bracelet was found in a jar of  glass beads. Knucklebones.
properties.Ship equipment: A stone anchor of Near Eastern type, was found about 100m away from the main site in 1994.

properties.Name: Antidragonera
properties.Reference: http://www.culture.gr/2/21/215/21502/e21503.html       Master Seafarers: the Phoenicians and the Greeks (Periplus, 2004), 128-129.
properties.Comments: The shipwreck has been excavated since 1993 under the direction of Dr. Dimitris Kourkoumelis. Finds to date include 9 large stone anchors, a few amphorae and at least two storage pithoi, probably belonging to the crew. The bulk of the cargo was probably perishable.
properties.Hull remains: A few bronze nails.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: 2 storage pithoi, plates, lamps, lekanides, pitchers, mortars, bowls etc.
properties.Ship equipment: 9 large pyramid shaped stone anchors, similar to those found in Zea port in Piraeus and the 4th-c. BC wrecks of La Madonnina in the Bay of Taranto, and Ognina 4 in Sicily. The first group lay at the head of the bay on the north side of the islet, at a fairly shallow depth of 9 meters, and included four anchors, the smaller of the two groups. These anchors were probably used by crews to secure the shipsβ� anchorage at the head of the bay. The second group included another five anchors, larger in size than the first group, 150 meters from the first group, towards the northeast headland of the islet. Four of these five anchors were recovered by the excavation team.

properties.Name: Bozburun Julio-Claudian
properties.Reference: http://www.rpmnautical.org/julioclaud.html         J. Royal, IJNA 35 (2006), 195-218
properties.Comments: A large amphora mound measuring 15 x 5m although it is hard to discerna stacking pattern as the upper amphorae are tumbled and there is a large amount of marine growth covering the site.

properties.Name: Bozburun Late Antiquity anchor
properties.Reference: http://www.rpmnautical.org/lateantiquity.html            J. Royal, IJNA 35 (2006), 195-218
properties.Comments: An oval shaped amphora deposit measuring 9 x 3m with 2  collections of anchors about 4m to the west and northwest of the amphorae.
properties.Ship equipment: There are at least 9, and possibly 11, anchors located in 2 deposits suggesting they were in their stowed postitions at the time of sinking. Seven have clearly discernable arms, six of which are of a cruciform shape (cf Dramont F and Yassi Ada wrecks). Only one has a 2m anchor stock

properties.Name: Bozburun Late Republican
properties.Reference: http://www.rpmnautical.org/laterepublicanwreck.htm               J. Royal, IJNA 37 (2008), 88-97
properties.Comments: A badly damaged mound of amphorae measuring 10 x 8m, rising to 0.5-0.75m, although many are still in their upright position in the sand, suggesting that the hull may be preserved underneath.
properties.Hull remains: Probable, still buried underneath the amphorae.

properties.Name: Porto Palo di Capo Passero
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 458  Basile 1997
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A louterion of clay with its stand.

properties.Name: Bozburun tile wreck
properties.Reference: http://www.rpmnautical.org/tilewreck.htm           J. Royal, IJNA 37 (2008), 88-97
properties.Comments: The site is a small mound measuring c 21 x 10m comprising both cover and pan tiles still in their stacked positions. A trail of amphorae starting about 10m from the site and continuing 600m away contains at least 3 concentrated depostis of numerous large body sherds and upper portions, a formation possibly caused by drag nets.
properties.Other cargo: Roof tiles, both cover and pan: over 10 of red fabric with white inclusions have been exposed possibly by an octupus (!). The cover tiles are about 1m long and 0.2-0.3m  wide, and slightly rounded to form a convex shape that is more acute at their edges than at the centre, stacked one upon the other and lying on their sides.

properties.Name: Monemvasia - Kremmydi
properties.Reference:
http://chronique.efa.gr/index.php/fiches/voir/127/                   Dellaporta, A., AD 54 (1999) [2006], p. 1023.
Spondilis, H., AD 54 (1999) [2006], p. 1025.
properties.Comments: Three Roman wrecks are reported in the bay of Kremmydi.

properties.Name: Secche della Circe
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2004/news0408.htm
properties.Comments: Presumably a cargo of amphorae.
properties.Hull remains: In good condition, the ship measured 20m x 6m.
properties.Ship equipment: An iron anchor has been brought up.

properties.Name: Bozburun Byzantine
properties.Reference: http://www.diveturkey.com/inaturkey/selimiye.htm        L. Dillon Gorham and V. Bryant, IJNA 30 (2001), 282-298;  S. Kingsley, Barbarian Seas: Late Rome to Islam (Periplus, 2004), 61-63; M. Harpster, IJNA 34 (2005), 88-94; M. Harpster, IJNA 38 (2009), 297-313           http://www.inadiscover.com/projects/all/southern_europe_mediterranean_aegean/bozburun_turkey/introduction/
properties.Comments: Dating changed since Parker 1992 as the site was re-examined by the INA from 1995-98. The hull remains provide some of the earliest evidence for the arithmetical design and construction methods that later dominated ship building in the Mediterranean.
properties.Hull remains: Quite well preserved with the keel and most of the starboard side of the bottom surviving. Probable size 15 x 5m. White oak keel and planking from NW Anatolia, felled in AD 874, unusual use but suggests emphasis on strength and durability. Construction sequence is notable as a mix of Classical period edge fastenings and frame-based design. Brushwood dunnage was still inplace between some of the amphorae.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: At least 10 cooking pots, all black with a nearly spherical body, a flared rim and 1 or 2 broad strap handles; 6 pitchers; 2 copper jugs; a set of 3 very fine glass goblets with a small, mould-blown glass bottle; a lamp amd a bronze steelyard beam with lead counterweight. A very small elephant tusk, the left antler of a deer and a lump of arsenic sulfide (for pigments)  were presumably personal items.Absence of coins and valuables suggest that the crew had time to collect their things and abandon ship.
properties.Ship equipment: An anchor, of typical early Byzantine cruciform pattern.

properties.Name: Polyaigos (marble)
properties.Reference: http://chronique.efa.gr/index.php/fiches/voir/544/          Dellaporta, A., Dimitriadou, Th., AD 54 (1999) [2006] B’2, p. 1031.
properties.Marble type: A single column of cipollino from Carystos was found that may come from an otherwise unknown wreck transporting architectural elements.

properties.Name: Polyaigos
properties.Reference: http://www.balkantravellers.com/en/read/article/1720              http://www.in.gr/news/article.asp?IngEntityID=1099326&IngDtrID=253
properties.Comments: The shipwreck, first spotted in 2004, was initially explored by underwater archaeologists in the fall of 2009. These excavations resulted in the discovery of valuable archaeological objects, including amphorae, ceramic vases and fragments of the vessel’s anchor. At least three types of amphorae were identified, one of which originated from ancient Peparithos (the island of Skopelos), while the others were closely identified with Classical Era amphorae workshops of the northern Aegean.
properties.Other cargo: Ceramic vases.
properties.Ship equipment: Parts of the ship's anchor were also found

properties.Name: Scauri
properties.Reference: G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 126                 http://www.regione.sicilia.it/beniculturali/archeologiasottomarina/prod_editoriali/op_scras/Opuscolo%20SCRAS-Pag%2023_31.pdf
properties.Comments: Discovered in 1997 and excavated in 1999, a cargo of ceramics on baord a ship that may have sunk due to an onboard fire.
properties.Other cargo: Ceramics - cylindrical pots, bowls and cups; glass bottles and beakers in fragments. Oil lamps and some Sigillata Africana D.
properties.Hull remains: Few remains
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Numerous remains of wildlife (especially teeth) including goat. A silver ring decorated with a piece of green glass.

properties.Name: Caucana
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2002/news0207.htm
properties.Comments: A vague report of a Byzantine wreck that seems to have been a merchant ship.

properties.Name: Camarina bronzes
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2000/news0011.htm#camarina
properties.Comments: A cargo of bronzes discovered in 2000.
properties.Other cargo: Bronze objects including oil lamps, bronzes similar to those found in the noble houses of Pompeii and Herculaneum, decorative pots, braziers, chandeliers and parts of statuettes of Mercury.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A 35 cm section of a small altar.

properties.Name: Pabuç Burnu
properties.Reference: http://ina.tamu.edu/yasymposium/PDFs/Greene.pdf                  http://ina.tamu.edu/pabucburnu/   Polzer, M.E. 2004. An Archaic Laced Hull in the Aegean: The 2003 Excavation and Study of the Pabuç Burnu Ship Remains. INA Quarterly 31.3: 3-11          E. Greene et al, AJA 112 (2008), 685-711
properties.Comments: Twenty-eight of the amphorae have been studied and there is a distinct lack of standardization in capacity despite relatively consistent linear dimensions. a modest-sized merchant vessel unlikely to have sailed beyond the immediate area between Rhodes and Miletus. The wreck, which carried an assortment of coarseware cups, bowls, and pitchers, along with about 250 amphoras that probably carried wine or olive oil. The site covers an area of 26m x 14m and was excavated in the early 2000s.
properties.Other cargo: A heavy concentration of grape seeds in the lower region of the site suggests that the ship also carried a bulk cargo of grapes or raisins, perhaps packed in sacks or baskets, which did not survive underwater.
properties.Hull remains: Construction features visible on six fragmentary planks recovered from the ship's hull reveal that it was laced together. Such lacing of planks appears in Homer's Odyssey where the hero builds a boat for his journey away from the island of Calypso (5.244-8). There is also evidence for an early adaptation of mortise and tenon joinery.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: An assemblage of plain wares (bowls, mortars, and pitchers) and Ionian cup sherds decorated with black slip. These are likely all of southern Ionian production.
properties.Ship equipment: A large, stone anchor stock from near the center of the site (M10). It has a wide notch carved at its mid-point, measures 1.65 m (5.4 ft) long, and weighs 115 kg. A similar shaped smaller stone anchor was found farther down the slope.

properties.Name: Yassi Ada A
properties.Reference: P. Van Alfen, JRA 9 (1996), 189-213; S. Kingsley, Barbarian Seas: Late Rome to Islam (Periplus, 2004), 45-52; http://ina.tamu.edu/yasymposium/PDFs/Van%20Doorninck2.pdf
properties.Comments: A well preserved 21m ship carrying 3 rows of about 900 amphorae. The ship can be dated from 16 gold coins and 50 copper coins to AD 626, as all but one gold coin were issues of the Emperor Heraclius. The ship may have belonged to the Church and was transporting low-grade wine intended for Byzantine troops. The ship, with a  slim 4:1 length to width ratio, sharp bow and full stern was designed for speed and carried a lateen sail. At the stern was a large galley complex, well equipped to serve food and drink to quite a number of passnegers.
properties.Hull remains: Well preserved. A fairly weak construction of widely spaced, small and unpeggedd mortise and tenon joints only up to the waterline; above that hull planking was fixed to already erected framing.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: At least 40 iron carpentry tools, numerous cooking wares and copper containers, coins, fishing equipment and 16 oil lamps. 8 bronze weights (and 1 of glass) and at least 3 steelyards, the largest of which is 1.46m long and decorated at one end with a boar's head terminal. Its sculptural counterweight was a bust of the goddess Athena. A bronze censer and cross.
properties.Ship equipment: 11 iron anchors with straight arms set perpendicular to the shank, a cruciform anchor design used from the C4th-10th AD. Three of the anchors weighed 78.75kg, another one 110.25kg and another three were sheet anchors weighing 141.75kg.

properties.Name: Yassi Ada B
properties.Reference: S. Kingsley, Barbarian Seas: Late Rome to Islam (Periplus, 2004), 51.
properties.Comments: A 19m long by 8m wide ship carrying 1,100 probably Aegean amphorae some of which are now displayed in the Bodrum Museum.
properties.Hull remains: The port side of the hull was well preserved up to the waterline. Mostly cypress wood but with a keel of white oak, with a shell-first construction. Mortise and tenon joints were used but are small and widely spaced and more easily assembled than they normally were in Roman hulls.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A spacious galley set down in the stern had a rough-stone firebox. At least 6 pantry jars, a funnel, 4 cooking pots, 11 pitchers, a cup, a bowl, 2 large plates, a smaller dish, 5 glass vessels, a copper jug, possibly 3 steelyards, some copper coins, a casting net and 4 lamps, 1 signed KY from an Athenian workshop.

properties.Name: Plemmirio B
properties.Reference: D. Gibbins, Antiquity 71 no.272 (1997) and World Archaeology 32 (2001), 311-334
properties.Comments: A cargo of North African amphorae which had been looted before excavation.
properties.Hull remains: Fragments of timber. The ship probably only measured 12-18m in length.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Surgeon's instruments including a wooden bandaging stick, 3 copper alloy scalpel handles, 2 with long slender dissectors suitable for opthalmic surgery, the 3rd was attached to a corroded iron instrument which may have been a solid cataract needle or cautery. Tiles and bricks from the galley's roof and hearth; at least 22 different items of table and kitchen pottery; 4 oil lamps; 2 glass vessels. fishing weights. Several individual amphorae
properties.Ship equipment: A sounding lead, one of the few to date later than the early Imperial period; ferrous concretions of anchors

properties.Name: Gela A
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 458; G. Fiorentini, in Quaderni dell'Istitituo di Archeologia della Facolta di Lettere e Filosofia della Universita di Messina 5 (1990), 25-39; G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 109- 13                                                                                                                                                                                                                http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7531639.stm for video of 2008 raising of hull
properties.Comments: The ship was constructed with the sewn technique.
properties.Other cargo: Pottery.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A bronze tripod, 4 small clay altars, a bone flute and stylus and 8 vegetal fibre baskets.

properties.Name: Gela B
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 458; F. Facenna, in  Atti del Convegno Nazionale di Archeologia Subacquea. Anzio 1996, (1997), 143-146.
properties.Comments: Survey of the hull began in 1997.
properties.Hull remains: Mortise and tenon technique seen in the hull construction although there is at least one sewn repair. The hull is protected by ballast stones cf Gela A.

properties.Name: Bay of Naousa
properties.Reference: Five wreck sites?

properties.Name: Korakia (Porto heli)
properties.Reference: http://www.ienae.gr/e107EN/page.php?3

properties.Name: Vlychos (Hydra)
properties.Reference: http://www.ienae.gr/e107EN/page.php?3

properties.Name: Metochi
properties.Reference: http://www.ienae.gr/e107EN/page.php?3

properties.Name: Point Iria
properties.Reference: http://www2.rgzm.de/navis/cargo/Iria/Iria.htm            Master Seafarers: The Phoenicians and the Greeks (Periplus, 2004), 105-111.
properties.Comments: Cypriotic origin, dated to ca 1200 BC, lying on 12-27 m depth. Transporting Cypriotic pottery. The ship was probably less than 10 m long. Investigated by the Hellenic Institute of Marine Archaeology in 1991-1995.
properties.Other cargo: 25 pieces of Mycenaean and Cypriot pottery, and Cretan transport jars. "Cypriot pithoi and LH/LM IIIB 2 pithoid jars) and medium size ones (Cretan stirrup-jars, Cypriot jugs and an amphora with incised linear signs)."  "a few decorated Mycenaean vases in fine ware (a deep bowl krater and one or two deep bowls)."
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A Cypriot heavy broad-based water jug (jug A20 or the 'Tsouchlos jug').

properties.Name: Sciacca
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 458
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Some lamps and amphorae.
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock.

properties.Name: Mazarron 1
properties.Reference: I. Negueruela, J. Pinedo et al, IJNA 24 (1995), 189-197  and 30 (2001); Master Seafarers: the Phoenicians and the Greeks (Periplus, 2004), 41-45.          http://inadiscover.com/projects/all/southern_europe_mediterranean_aegean/mazarron_timber_study_spain/introduction/            http://www2.rgzm.de/navis/ships/Ship058/Ship058Engl.htm
properties.Comments: A small C 7th BC ship discovered in 1994 during the building of a marina on the Playa de la Isla and excavated in 1999. The ship measured only 5.5 x 1.3m but 7,500 artefacts have been recovered, the majority of which may have been the crew's possessions.  The planks of the hull are joined with pegged mortises and tenons; the frames of the ship, however, are lashed. In addition, the edges of the planks are beveled and sewn. The Mazarrón 1 appears to be an extremely important transitional ship for the study and understanding of shipbuilding evolution in antiquity.
properties.Other cargo: Urns, baskets, mortars, religious objects and carafes.
properties.Hull remains: Well preserved hull buried under a thin layer of sand. Some keel fragments were preserved measuring 4m and 9 planks were attached to the hull by mortise and tenon joints. The hull was coated in resin. Several pieces of petrified rope were also discovered.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Flat and round-bottomed plates, pots and pans. A finely crafted silver scarab ring and a bronze spear.

properties.Name: Aci Trezza 1
properties.Reference: http://www.sportesport.it/wrecksSI015.htm
properties.Hull remains: Tiles from the cabin.
properties.Ship equipment: Lead and iron anchors

properties.Name: Aci Trezza 2
properties.Reference: http://www.sportesport.it/wrecksSI015.htm
properties.Comments: This second ship was found near the harbour of the Southern rock of Ciclopi Islets.
properties.Other cargo: A cargo of millstones, of which 20 have been recovered and are now exhibited at Naxos Antiquarium.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A beautiful lead  "Romano da Stadera",  (a balance weight) representing Athena  was found between two rocks: it was probably used as a sound.

properties.Name: Porto Palo di Menfi
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, (2002), p. 458; B. Basile, in Atti del Convegno Nazionale di Archaologia Subacquea. Anzio 1996,  (1997), 147-152                        http://www.regione.sicilia.it/beniculturali/archeologiasottomarina/prod_editoriali/op_scras/Opuscolo%20SCRAS-Pag%2023_31.pdf            http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/77/6/archeologi-in-fondo-al-mare-di-gianfranco-purpura.html
properties.Comments: Excavated by the G.I.A.S.S. Group, the site covers an area 16 x 6m, unusually for Sicily is in shallow waters.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Ceramics including a pyx with black paint, maybe an inkwell, and fragments of dishes and cups

properties.Name: Capo Feto
properties.Reference: G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 127     http://www.regione.sicilia.it/beniculturali/archeologiasottomarina/sez_eventi/capo%20feto.htm
properties.Hull remains: A portion of the keel and part of the stern.
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast stones

properties.Name: Marsala A
properties.Reference: G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 116; M. Bonino, Archaeologia Mediterranea maritima 2007, 179-190
properties.Hull remains: The remains show the early development of the skeleton building technique on a ship that measured 15.5m x 4.5m

properties.Name: Preveto
properties.Comments: The first Arab wreck found in Sicilian waters.
properties.Other cargo: Cups, pitchers and bowls. Many tiles.
properties.Hull remains: The ship measured at least 25m long

properties.Name: Trapani
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 458
properties.Comments: Excavated by the G.I.A.S.S. Group.
properties.Hull remains: A section is preserved.

properties.Name: Capo d'Armi
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html  site 134, area 17
properties.Comments: The probable remains of a a cargo of amphorae.

properties.Name: Ithaki 2
properties.Reference: www.norwinst.gr/Feltarbeid/Ithaki.htm (2000); K. Delaporta et al. IJNA 35 (2006), 79-87.
properties.Comments: A cargo of several thousand amphorae froma ship estimated to have been 25m long.

properties.Name: Ithaki 4
properties.Reference: www.norwinst.gr/Feltarbeid/Ithaki.htm (2000); K. Delaporta et al. IJNA 35 (2006), 79-87.
properties.Comments: A cargo of lead ingots.
properties.Other cargo: Lead ingots.

properties.Name: Ithaki 3
properties.Reference: www.norwinst.gr/Feltarbeid/Ithaki.htm (2000); K. Delaporta et al. IJNA 35 (2006), 79-87.
properties.Comments: A cargo of roof tiles.
properties.Other cargo: Roof tiles.

properties.Name: Cala Minnola
properties.Reference: http://www.regione.sicilia.it/beniculturali/archeologiasottomarina/
properties.Comments: A cargo of Dr 1B amphorae much looted before its excavation in 2005. It is now on CCTV to allow people to see the wreck from dry land.
properties.Hull remains: Some fragments of wood.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Fragments of coarseware and black-gloss pottery.
properties.Ship equipment: Lead pipes from  the bilge pump, an anchor.

properties.Name: Petousi
properties.Reference: http://chronique.efa.gr/index.php/fiches/voir/449/       Ethnos 5/11/2007
properties.Comments: A Roman shipwreck was found at this islet outside Styra. The cargo contained many 2nd−3rd Ct AD African amphorae for olive oil, of a type probably manufactured in Libya or Tunisia and generally found in the W Mediterranean (this is the first cargo in Greek waters).

properties.Name: San Vito Lo Capo
properties.Reference: F. Faccenna, Il Relitto di San Vito Lo Capo (2006)
properties.Comments: A local Sicilian ship carrying amphorae and jars cf Marsala A and B wrecks.

properties.Name: Porticello
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html  site 39, area 17C. Eiseman and B. Ridgway, The Porticello Wreck (1987); M. Lawall, IJNA 27 (1998) 16-23; M. Polzer, IJNA 37 (2008), 225-252
properties.Comments: A much looted ship measuring about 16.6m long with a cargo of mixed amphorae from the northern Aegean and the western Mediterranean, and an array of bronze sculpture.
properties.Other cargo: At least two dozen lead ingots, looted, only 2 have been excavated that are stamped, probably from Laurion. Eight small clay inkpots. Bronze sculpture: a superb male bearded  head, approximately life size, cast in 2 sections; a fragment of right leg and buttock with drapery; a large fragment of drapery; a left hand; the rear protion of a left foot; right foot and leg; genitals; left buttock and thigh; right buttock and upper thigh; other miscellaneous fragments - in total, probably at least one draped male and two undraped males.
properties.Hull remains: Few fragments of the hull survive. Several dozen copper nails, round-headed and square shafted. Lead patches.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Lamps, oinochoe, Attic black glaze pottery, coarse ware, mortar, whetstones, a wooden bowl, an awl and a sheep or goat bone. Four fragmentary black-glaze bolsals. Metal objects include lead fishing weights and cake ingots and lead and silver nuggets.
properties.Ship equipment: Several anchors : a wooden shank, wooden arms with bronze teeth and a wooden stock with lead cores. Other lead anchors may have been looted prior to excavation. A wooden bobbin toggle, with rigging, attaching lines to clews and luffs.

properties.Name: Kizil Burun Column
properties.Reference:
http://ina.tamu.edu/kizilburun/index.htm
D. Carlson, INA Quarterly 31.1 (2004), 3-9; J. Daniel, INA Quarterly 31.1 (2004), 13-14; K. Trego, INA Quarterly 31.1 (2004), 11-12; D. Carlson,  INA Quarterly 33.1(2006), 1-10; J. Daniel,  INA Quarterly 33.1 (2006), 13-14; K. Trego,  INA Quarterly 33.1 (2006), 11-12; D. Carlson, INA Quarterly 34.1 (2007), 3-10;  D. Hamilton and D. Carlson, The INA Annual 2008 Projects (2009), 11-14.
properties.Comments: Discovered in 1993 and excavated between 2005 and 2009, this is the wreck of a navis lapidaria which carried a cargo of newly quarried Proconnesian marble columns seemingly destined for the Temple of Apollo in Claros, Turkey.
properties.Marble type: Eight Proconnesian marble column drums averaging about 3 feet tall and ranging in diameter from 5 to 5.5 feet. This incremental graduation suggests that the eight drums and one capital comprise a single column over 30 feet tall. Newly quarried stone as the drums are not fluted and still preserve traces of corkscrew-shaped hoisting grooves. A group of large rectangular marble blocks which probably represent architectural elements associated with the column. This area also yielded an interesting array of newly-quarried, roughly-finished marble objects such as a small hand basin, the pedestal for one of two larger basins, and at least 6 uninscribed grave stones or stele. More than a dozen marble blocks.
properties.Other cargo: Undecorated, utilitarian cookware (plates, casseroles). Numerous Italian ceramics including cooking pans. Several types of typical Hellenistic fineware (moldmade bowls, grey ware, and black glaze cups, bowls, and salt cellars).Nine bronze handles.
properties.Hull remains: More than 250 fasteners, most of them copper nails and enough small but well-preserved wood fragments to suggest that some hull remains have survived beneath one or more of the drums. At least 24 timbers have been sent for analysis and some of the transverse timbers were made of ash.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: The head of a double axe, an axe-adze, a tool for removing nails, a chisel, (all in concretion). The remains of a large metal cauldron, an intact ceramic jug and a terracotta herm figurine. A worn and corroded bronze coin, probably Greek.
properties.Ship equipment: An anchor (in concretion, which with two lead anchor collars shows the transition from the use of wooden anchors to the introduction of iron anchors), a lead sounding weight, and an elaborate iron concretion that probably represents an important part of the ship's equipment.

properties.Name: Punta Mazza
properties.Reference: A. Freschi, in G. Tigano (ed.) Rinvenimenti Subacquei a Milazzo e il Relitto di Punta Mazzo (Messina, 1997), 60-65; A. Olla, ibid., 65-98.
properties.Comments: A large quantity of amphorae. Seven types, the main three are two sizes of Knossos 18, one-handled Agora F65-66 probably from the Ephesus area and Dr. 30. from Cilicia. There are also three Agora G199 from Paphos and some Zemer 57 from Palestine. Two other types are unidentifiable though resemble Syro-Palestinan. Many fragments of others from Asia Minor.
properties.Other cargo: Corinthian relief cups showing the exploits of Heracles, battle scenes, ritual scenes and hunting scenes.
properties.Hull remains: Lead sheathing, bronze and iron nails.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Tiles from the roof of the cabin, bronze lamps and cups.
properties.Ship equipment: Pump, lead anchor stock.

properties.Name: Agios Andreas
properties.Reference: Ethnos 05/11/2007          http://chronique.efa.gr/index.php/fiches/voir/450/
properties.Comments: A shipwreck was discovered with a cargo of C5th-6th AD amphorae.

properties.Name: Chios Straits
properties.Reference: B.P.  Foley and M.C. Hansson, Journal of Archaeological Science  35 (2008), 1169−76; Eleutheros Typos, Ta Nea 05/11/2007                           AR 51 (2004−2005), 90; AR 52 (2005−2006), 97    D. Sakellariou et al, IJNA 36 (2007), 365-381    B. Foley et al, Hesperia 78 (2009), 269-305                                                                                         http://www.whoi.edu/sbl/liteSite.do?litesiteid=2740&articleId=5698
properties.Comments: A C4th BC wreck found in the straits between Chios and Oinousses during a 2004 sonar survey by HCMR scientists and Ephorate archaeologists. . Over 400 concentrated artefacts form a longitudinal body of high reflectivity which rises to by 1.5-2m above the sea floor.

properties.Name: Punta di Zambrone
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html   site 133, area 18
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck with sparse fragments of amphorae.

properties.Name: Cala Piomba
properties.Reference: Etienne & Mayet 198-9.no. 50        http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/2/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html
properties.Comments: A cargo of amphorae spread over an area 50 x30m.
properties.Other cargo: Two lead ingots of trapezoidal shape.

properties.Name: Capo Bianco
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html   site 26, area 14                 http://www.reitia.it/nave_lapidaria_di_capo_bianco.html         http://www.reitia.it/archeologia_subacquea_nel_crotonese.php
properties.Comments: Excavated 1991, this is another navis lapidaria discovered in shallow water off Calabria.
properties.Marble type: Blocks of heterogeneous dimensions and drums of columns, distributed in a chaotic manner among the rocks. One of the larger blocks had been worked to create a semi-column on one of the long sides. The marble is of 3 different types.

properties.Name: Teulada
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2003/news0311.htm#cagliari
properties.Comments: A massive mound, 4m high and 20 or 30m long, of 5 types of amphora was found in 1998.

properties.Name: Seleno
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html    site 88, area 14
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck with a  cargo of scattered pieces of pottery in poor condition.
properties.Hull remains: Apiece of wood of modest dimensions but heavily eaten by termites.

properties.Name: Capo Colonna and Capo Alfieri
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html         site 18, area 14
properties.Comments: A probable Late Roman shipwreck of amphorae.

properties.Name: Punta Tonnara
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/2/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html

properties.Name: Mezzaluna
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/2/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html
properties.Comments: The hull of this medieval ship whose cargo was amphorae is currently covered by sand.
properties.Hull remains: At the time of survey (1989) the shell of this 18-20m long ship was exposed and between the frames were the remains of two boxes of iron about. 2 x 1m each, covered by concretions.

properties.Name: East Porto Pino
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/2/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html
properties.Comments: The remains of a cargo vessel which extends over an area of about 20 x 20m.
properties.Hull remains: None.

properties.Name: Porto Pino
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/2/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html
properties.Comments: A 10m long site of African amphorae.

properties.Name: Guardia de su Turcu
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/2/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html

properties.Name: Cantafora B
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html         site 20, area 14
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck of semi-worked blocks of marble.
properties.Marble type: An accumulation of semi-worked blocks distributed in a disorderly manner and slightly overlying one another. Several of the column drums, with a diameter of 70cm, are already prepared with the hole for fixing the the column cut in the centre of the circumference.

properties.Name: Capo Colonna, Cicala
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html site 19, area 14
properties.Comments: A cargo of architectural material.
properties.Marble type: Blocks of considerable dimensions, 6-7m in length, including 2 coumn drums with a diameter of c70cm and a length of 4-5m. The blocks laid as headers and sitting on their long sides are stacked without any particular order and are mostly parallelepiped or cubed in form and all are semi-worked and carved.

properties.Name: Vasiliko Bay Byzantine wrecks
properties.Reference: K. Delaporta et al, IJNA 35 (2006), 79-88
properties.Comments: Two large Byzantine shipwreck amphora mounds lie close to one another; a third was found a few hundred metres away in 2001 by the Greek-Norwegian deep-water archaeological survey team.Several hundred amphorae form a mound 17.5m long.

properties.Name: Alonnisos
properties.Reference: E. Hadjidaki, BCH 120 (1996), 561-593; Master Seafarers: The Phoenicians and the Greeks (Periplus, 2004), 112-113.
properties.Comments: A Classical wreck carrying at least 3 layers of amphorae was found near the island of Peristea.The wreck site covers an a rea 30 x 10m from which more than 4000 well preserved wine amphorae were found. The layering of the cargo gives a good idea of the route taken, Athenina pottery at the bottom, with the amphorae on top. The presence of carbon suggest that the ship sank due to fire, although it may also have been overloaded.
properties.Other cargo: High quality black-glazed pottery, the best of which came from Athens, including skyphoi, cups decorated with petals, drinking vessels. Heavy terracotta mortars with 2 handles, a large base and a thick rounded lip. Bowls with black-glazed bases from southern Italy.
properties.Hull remains: Bronze nails.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: An elegant pitcher, a chytra and a number of metal objects.
properties.Ship equipment: 2 lead cross bars from an anchor

properties.Name: Agios Petros Byzantine
properties.Reference: K. Delaporta et al, IJNA 35 (2006), 79-87
properties.Comments: Partly excavated in the 1970s, this wreck was re-examined in 2001 during a Greek-Norwegian deep water archaeology survey.

properties.Name: Agios Petros classical
properties.Reference: F. Haniotis, Archaeologikon Deltion 49 (1994), 862-64; K. Delaporta et al, IJNA 35 (2006), 79-87
properties.Comments: The earliest classical shipwreck found, with a cargo of Mendean amphorae.

properties.Name: Torre Melissa - Villaggio Sirio
properties.Dating: end of the C2nd- end C1st BC
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html        site 33, area 13
properties.Comments: The site is almost completely covered in sand. Several sporadic pottery fragmments are visible.
properties.Hull remains: A fragment of wood, heavily compromised by parasites and by xlophagous organisms.s

properties.Name: Tilegrafo Bay
properties.Reference: http://www.ienae.gr/e107EN/page.php?5
properties.Comments: Eight  wrecks were discovered dating to the late Roman and Byzantine periods. One of these, Wreck 7, was considered worth investigating more thoroughly. Wreck 7 is located in Tilegrafo Bay, 5 nautical miles south of Amaliapoli, and dates to the late 4th c. of the Christian era, i.e. the later Roman period. This is a significant wreck, preserved in reasonably good condition, carrying wine amphorae of at least five different types. One of the four  was previously unknown to archaeologists.

properties.Name: Gallipoli 2
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2003/news0307.htm#gallipoli
properties.Comments: One of two wrecks found by chance by police a mile from the coast between Gallipoli and Santa Maria di Leuca. Twenty-five amphorae were seized from looters and other artefacts but thee are no other details.

properties.Name: Gallipoli 3
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2003/news0307.htm#gallipoli
properties.Comments: One of two wrecks found by chance by police a mile from the coast between Gallipoli and Santa Maria di Leuca. Twenty-five amphorae were seized from looters and other artefacts but thee are no other details.

properties.Name: Torre Sinfono
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html        site 139, area 9
properties.Comments: At least two, maybe three layers of overlying amphorae still in their original position. Some looting has taken place.

properties.Name: Mal di Ventre
properties.Reference: D. Salvi, Bollettino di Archeologia 1992, 237-248C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, (2002),  460; Salvi, 1992; G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 89-95.
properties.Comments: A large merchant ship, estimated at 30m x 9m, carrying a cargo mainly of lead ingots, the biggest haul found so far.
properties.Other cargo: 1100 Spanish lead ingots mined from Cartagena, each weighing about 100 Roman pounds and inscribed on theupper side with the manufacturer's mark. One was SOCMPONTILIENORUMMAE, ie Societas Marci et Caio Pontilienorum figli di Marco. The other LCARULILFHISPALIMN, ie. Luci Caruli Luci fili Hispali MeNenia tribu.
properties.Hull remains: The keel seems to have been strengthened with bronze nails to support the enormous weight of its cargo (cf Capo Testa wreck).
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Dressel 1 amphorae and coarseware pottery. A millstone
properties.Ship equipment: Three lead and wood anchors, 2 lead sounding weights.

properties.Name: Gallipoli 1
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html              site 143, area 9
properties.Ship equipment: Two groups of at least 5 large iron anchors; 2  are still upright, of which one has its stock still attached. Further away but on the same longitudinal line, are 2  other large completely conserved anchors, one with its shank.

properties.Name: Capo Palinuro - Punta della Quaglia
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html  site 217, area 21
properties.Comments: The wide spread of the material and the size of the anchor stock suggest that this was a large vessel. However the anchor shank only provides a general chronology, as it can be dated over a wide period.
properties.Hull remains: Part of the planking still in position.
properties.Ship equipment: A complete anchor stock, 3m long. A tube about 15cm long, probably made of lead, bent at one end, possibly part of the bilge pump. Several metal objects lying in an upright position,  may belong to part of an anchor shank.

properties.Name: Mandriola A
properties.Reference: P. Spanu, Tharros Felix-2 (2006), 181ff
properties.Comments: A late Roman Spanish/African cargo, similar to Cala Reale (L'Asinara ) wreck.
properties.Other cargo: Many fragments of African table ware.

properties.Name: Cala Su Pallosu
properties.Reference: E. Solinas and I. 147-Sanna, Tharros Felix-2 (2006), 147-151; D Salvi, Tharros Felix-2 (2006), 154-160.
properties.Comments: A cargo of millstones, some glass and cups.
properties.Other cargo: Millstones - 4 lower cone-shaped parts (metae) and 5 upper parts (catilli). Glass. Cups.

properties.Name: Sa Tonnara A
properties.Reference: E. Sechi, Tharros-Felix 2 (2006), 164 ff.
properties.Comments: Amphorae of these types had previously been brought to the surface without excavation of the site in the 1970s and 80s. It seems reasonable to assume that this is a site of a shipwreck.

properties.Name: Mucurune
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html        site 6, area 8
properties.Comments: The site area can be identified by a wide spread of amphorae sherds.
properties.Ship equipment: A large 2m anchor, heavily concreted, lying with the shaft and arms resting against a large block.

properties.Name: Santa Caterina di Nardo
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html              site 7, area 9

properties.Name: Santa Caterina di Nardo 2
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html      site 161, area 9
properties.Other cargo: Cooking ware.
properties.Ship equipment: Large river stones, clearly not associated  to the geomorphology of the site and are therefore to be considered as ballast.

properties.Name: Cala Palombara
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html       site 149, area 8
properties.Comments: The site is covered with scattered pieces of amphorae attached to the seabad or amassed inside the cavaties if the rocks.

properties.Name: Nardo
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html       site 164, area 9
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck.

properties.Name: Punta Licosa 2
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html   site 59, area 22
properties.Comments: A probable wreck although no hull fragments were discovered, and various random amphorae were found nearby - an archaic Greek C6th, Lamboglia 2/Dressel 6 and the base of a medieval jar.
properties.Marble type: About 15-20  blocks with dimensions varying from 50 to 100cm which have clearly been squared

properties.Name: Punta Licosa 1
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html       site 51, area 22                 C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 459
properties.Comments: Excavation and recovery 1990-1995 of the cargo of amphorae.
properties.Hull remains: Several wooden fragments.
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock and a piece of lead tubing, probably part of the bilge pump.

properties.Name: Torre Chianca
properties.Reference: Unpublished, Parker (1992), 1153.                                                                                                                             http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html               site 155, area 9
properties.Comments: A shipwreck of Dr. 43 (AC 4) wine amphorae from Crete and marble columns.
properties.Marble type: Five marble columns, 8-9m long of cipollino, lying approximately 50cm apart, still in the original position in which they were transported. Another 2 are still buried in sand.
properties.Other cargo: A lead seal marked with a Greek monogram and a star.

properties.Name: La Speranza
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/3/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html
properties.Comments: A totally shattered wreck of Dr 8-9 amphorae spread over a 100m sq area.
properties.Other cargo: Concretions of iron items?
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A bowl, broken Dr 7-11 amphorae

properties.Name: Torre Chianca (Lecce)
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html             sites 81, 167 and 168  area 7
properties.Comments: Three connected sites that may well be one shipwreck.
properties.Hull remains: A 3m x 20cm piece of wood, probably part of a keelson. Close by are at least 5 pieces of planking and other external planking boards, all mortise and tenon. Lead sheathing found on site 168 may be part of the same hull. Part of a keel found at site 167 may be part of the same hull too.

properties.Name: Bocca Grande
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html                 archeomar site 80, area 25
properties.Comments: The deposit measures approximately 15-16m in length and 8m in width and rises from the seabed about 3-4m.

properties.Name: Alghero 1
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 460; P Spanu (personal communication to Beltrame).

properties.Name: Punta dell'Arcera
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html                site 180, area 25              http://www.archeomar.it/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=21&Itemid=35#relitti
properties.Comments: A large accumulation of amphorae seemingly still in their original vertical position, with an inclination of between 30-40 degreeswith respect to the seabed. A few amphorae lie randomly on top.

properties.Name: Bocca Piccola 1
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html  site 178, area 25
properties.Comments: Fragments of amphorae possibly belonging to a wreck.

properties.Name: Bocca Piccola 2
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html   site 189, area 25               http://www.archeomar.it/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=21&Itemid=35#relitti
properties.Comments: A long, oval mound of amphorae measuring approximately 12m by 2.5m with a height of about 80-100cm.

properties.Name: Capo Galera
properties.Reference: P. Spanu, in Atti del Convegno Mazionale di Archeologia Subacquea. Anzio 1996 (1997), 109-119; C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana (2002), 462
properties.Comments: An Islamic cargo investigated in the 1990s.
properties.Other cargo: Glazed pottery - bowls, plates and casseroles.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Sandals, a silver pitcher and a musical wind instrument.

properties.Name: Lazzaretto B
properties.Reference: http://members.xoom.it/crasa/cracur.htm

properties.Name: Li Galli - Vetara
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html  site 260, area 25
properties.Comments: Heavily looted complete cargo of amphorae of which only two remain since its discovery 40 years ago.

properties.Name: Lazzaretto A
properties.Reference: http://members.xoom.it/crasa/lazzaa.htm

properties.Name: Punta del Serrone
properties.Reference: I Bronzi di Punta del Serrone: Ricerche Archeologiche Subacquee a Brindisi 1992, Bollettino di Archeologia, (Puglia, 1992); C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana (2002), 457; G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 137-46.
properties.Comments: A cargo of amphorae and bronze statues was excavated in the early 1990s. The bronzes may have belonged to a collector or they may have been a cargo of metal ready for recasting.
properties.Other cargo: A bronze foot (45cm) was found in 1972, followed by another 150 pieces of bronze sculpture in 1992 in an area 15m x 10m. Another foot, two statues, one late Hellenistic male nude, another Augustan male in a toga (1.47m). Seven bronze heads are better conserved, two date to the C4th BC, one with a short beard to the Late Hellenistic period, another male head and two female heads to the early Imperial period, and a final male head to late Imperial times. This was either a ship carrying works of art belonging to a private collector or a cargo of metal ready for recasting.
properties.Hull remains: Some pieces of lead sheathing are all that remain on the rocky bottom.
properties.Ship equipment: A sounding lead and a lead ring.

properties.Name: Isole Pedagne Grandi
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html          site 5, area 6
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck with a variety of very fragmented pottery, including amphorae, coarse ware and glazed pieces, with assorted pieces of wood.
properties.Marble type: Various broken pieces of an unidentified column.
properties.Hull remains: Assorted pieces of wood.

properties.Name: Çamalti Burnu 1
properties.Reference: http://www.nautarch.org/camalti.htm        "Marmara Adasi, Camalti Burnu I Batigi-1999/2000", XXIII. Kazi Sonuclari Sempozyumu, Ankara, 2002, p. 381-390     "Camalti Burnu I Batigi", Bogazici Universitesi, 2002 Sualti Bilim ve Teknolojisi Toplantisi, Istanbul, (2002), p. 51-54         "Camalti Burnu I Wreck - 98/99 Field Seasons", VIIth International Symposium on Ship Construction in Antiquity, Tropis VII (Atina), 2002, p. 391-399; N. Gunsenin, Anatalia Antiqua IX (2001), 117-133;  Anatolia Antiqua XI, Paris (2003), 361-376
properties.Comments: Over an area 42m x 18m, at least 800 stamped amphorae have been found on a 25m long merchant ship that had 2 masts and a half deck. The amphorae on this wreck have been dated to the thirteenth century , placing them among the last amphorae in large-scale commercial use. Some of them had stamps and graffitti and wooden stoppers.
properties.Other cargo: Other types of storage jars and two or three dozen broken anchors destined to be repaired or used as scrap iron.
properties.Hull remains: Poorly preserved due to marine organisms. Only 1m of the keel, a few frame segments, a short length of bilge wale and the traceable remains of perhaps 6 strakes.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Various high quality ceramics including one handled jars, cooking pots, decorated glazed plates, a sgraffito plate and a cup.
properties.Ship equipment: Three anchors, 2 Y type and 1 T type.

properties.Name: Çamalti Burnu 2
properties.Reference: http://www.nautarch.org/sites.htm

properties.Name: Cala del Falco 1
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/3/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html
properties.Other cargo: In the late '70s a 4m long lead bar was still visible.

properties.Name: Cala del Falco 2
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/115/3/rinvenimenti-archeologici-subacquei-in-sardegna-sud-occ.html
properties.Comments: A second Roman wreck in the bay.
properties.Ship equipment: Two lead anchor stocks.

properties.Name: Anataş  Adacik (Palapetra)
properties.Reference: N. Gunsenin, Archaeonautica 14 (1998), 312         http://www.nautarch.org/sites.htm
properties.Ship equipment: A Y type anchor

properties.Name: Torre Testa - Porto di Brindisi
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html            site 271, area 6
properties.Comments: A range of pottery spread over a vast area of silt and debris. Maybe a shipwreck that has been disturbed by the continuous passage of lare ships.

properties.Name: Ischia
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2002/news0203.htm#ischia
properties.Comments: Artefacts were found suggesting a Roman ship that also seems to be a bireme.

properties.Name: Ottiolu
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2003/news0306.htm#ottiolu
properties.Marble type: Finished grey, fine-grained marble slabs, possibly from Luna.
properties.Hull remains: Some fragments of wood and some nails.

properties.Name: Torre Santa Sabina 1
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana (2002), 457

properties.Name: Torre Santa Sabina 2
properties.Reference: F. Zongolo, Atti del Convegno Nazionale de Archeologia Subacquea: Antium May-June 1996 (1997), 245-249; C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana (2002), 457
properties.Hull remains: The outline of the ship is visible and construction points to mortise and tenon joints.

properties.Name: Marina Grande di Bacoli
properties.Dating: 2nd half C1st BC- end C1st AD
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html               archeomar site 53, area 25
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck as there are several intact amphorae in what looks like their original position.
properties.Other cargo: Numerous fragments of unidentified pottery.

properties.Name: Cala Rossano
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 459; F. Arata,  Archeologia Subacquea. Studi, ricerche e documenti 1 (1993), 131-151.
properties.Comments: A partially looted site excavated in 1990.
properties.Ship equipment: Elements of the bilge pump are all that remain.

properties.Name: Golfo di Pozzuoli
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html  site 211, area 25
properties.Comments: The site of a probable shipwreck with a cargo of various African amphorae.

properties.Name: Golfo di Pozzuoli (Le Crastole)
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html             archeomar site 57, area 25

properties.Name: Baia Salinedda (San Teodoro)
properties.Reference: G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 104              http://www.icimar.it/museo/relitto_baia_salinedda.htm
properties.Comments: The remains of a ship and its contents spread over an area approximately 14.7m x 4m excavared in the 1990s.
properties.Other cargo: Ceramics, glass and metal?
properties.Hull remains: Three sections reamin: the larger fragment (4.7 x 1.95 m) consists of nine exterior planks, another fragment comes from the ceiling, while another section is of frames and shell plating covering an area of 2.6 m x 2m.  The predominant species of wood used for the construction are those so-called Mediterranean pines (Pinus pinaster, Pinus halepensis), although oak and olive are also found.

properties.Name: Napoli A
properties.Reference: D. Giampola et al, Archeologia Maritima Mediterranea (2005), 63-91; C.  Capretti et al, Archaeometry 50 (2008), 855-876
properties.Comments: The 3 Napoli ships, A, B and C were found during construction work for the underground and are well preserved due to their submersion in mud and silt.
properties.Hull remains: Excellent condition. The remains of the hull measure 11.77m by 3.32m wide and were coated in resin. Many repairs can be seen.

properties.Name: Napoli B
properties.Dating: end of C1st- beg C2nd AD
properties.Reference: D. Giampola et al, Archeologia maritima Mediterranea (2005), 63-91; C.  Capretti et al, Archaeometry 50 (2008), 855-876
properties.Comments: Although fairly well preserved, this ship is not as intact as Napoli A.
properties.Hull remains: The intact hull remains measure 8m by 2m.

properties.Name: Napoli C
properties.Reference: D. Giampola et al, Archeologia maritima Mediterranea (2005), 63-91; C.  Capretti et al, Archaeometry 50 (2008), 855-876
properties.Comments: This ship was probably used only for loading and unloading within the port of Naples.
properties.Hull remains: Excellent remains, measuring 13.2m by 3.7m.

properties.Name: Siciliano (Porto San Paolo)
properties.Reference: R. D'Oriano, Bollettino di Archaeolgia 46-48 (1997), 81-82; E. Riccardi, Bollettino di Archaeolgia 46-48 (1997), 82-86; G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 104
properties.Other cargo: Ceramics: Ostia III 267 and Ostia I 17 plates.
properties.Hull remains: Two sections of the hull are preserved, part of the bottom (5.65m of the keel) and part of the right side; some lead sheathing and repairs. The ship measured between 15 and 20m long and was built with great care.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Part of an oil lamp and a coin dated to the C2nd, pointing to the long history of the ship; ceramics and part of a bronze pin.

properties.Name: Coscia di Donna
properties.Region: Near Punta del Francese, north-west Sardinia
properties.Reference: http://archeogate.it/subacquea/article.php?id=115&offset=3
properties.Comments: A cargo of marble.
properties.Marble type: A central file of three blocks of white marble 2.2msq.; on each side are four rectangular blocks 2.8m x 1.2m x 0.8m; at the end, four rectangular blocks of the same dimensions. A total of about 100m cubed, weighing 265-275 tons. Could be Luna marble but not certain. Small black and white marble chips, possibly from earlier voyages.
properties.Hull remains: No hull remains but the ship was probably 17.65m long with a breadth of 7.8m, judging by the neat position of the marble blocks.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Some shipboard ceramics under the marble, including Gauloise 5, Agora M254 and Dr.12.
properties.Ship equipment: Lead anchor stock 5m from the marble blocks.

properties.Name: Olbia Late Roman 1
properties.Reference: R. D'Oriano, Archeologia in Sardegna, 2007,  98-103                                                                                                                                   http://www.archeosub.it/news2000/news0009.htm#olbia
properties.Comments: At least eleven C5th shipwrecks found during construction work of the tunnel in Olbia and excavated between 1999 and 2001. They are lying side by side and have been burned and sunk. This was correlated with the assault and destruction of the city by the Vandals in the C5th AD. The area in fact corresponds to the port of ancient Olbia.
properties.Hull remains: Remains of nine Late Roman wrecks, some of which were as long as 30m. Four rudders over 8m long, only seen previously in the now burnt Lake Nemi ships. Characteristics of transition between the technical construction of  Greek-Roman to Medieval shipbuilding can be seen.

properties.Name: Olbia Roman Imperial
properties.Reference: E. Riccardi, IJNA 31 (2002) 268-269; R. D'Oriano, Archeologia in Sardegna, 2007,  98-103
properties.Comments: Two C1st AD merchant ships that had sunk in a flood were found during the construction work in Olbia and excavated between 1999 and 2001. In this area was also found the remains of a naval shipyard and amongst these remains, a 7.6m length of a mast was found (probably half its original length).
properties.Other cargo: Oil lamps and glassware.

properties.Name: Olbia (statue)
properties.Reference: G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 104
properties.Comments: Discovered in 1990.
properties.Other cargo: Fragments of a terracotta statue of Hercules.

properties.Name: Olbia Late Roman 2
properties.Reference: R. D'Oriano, Archeologia in Sardegna, 2007,  98-103
properties.Comments: Three other C5th AD wrecks found during construction works in Olbia and excavated between 1999 and 2001.

properties.Name: Olbia medieval
properties.Reference: R. D'Oriano, Archeologia in Sardegna, 2007,  98-103
properties.Comments: Five small wrecks from the eleventh, fourteenth and fifteenth centuries have been found during construction work in Olbia and excavated between 1999 and 2001.

properties.Name: Yenikapi
properties.Reference: U. Kocabas (ed.), The Old ships of the New Gate, vol I (2008)                               http://inadiscover.com/projects/all/southern_europe_mediterranean_aegean/yenikapi_harbor_wrecks_turkey/introduction/
properties.Comments: Thirty-four wrecks have been found in the remains of a former harbour, the Portus Theodosiacus, and are in the process of being excavated. One is a galley and at least 9 are merchant ships measuring from 8m to 19m.
properties.Hull remains: Many of the timbers are well preserved, with original tool marks and intricate detail.

properties.Name: L'Asinara 2
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 460; P. Spanu, Atti del Convegno Nazionale di Archaologia Subacquea. Anzio 1996, (1997), 109-119.          http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/678/1/trovati-due-relitti-nei-fondali-del-golfo-dellasinara.html
properties.Comments: A very deep wreck of Lusitanian amphorae examined by ROV in 2007.
properties.Other cargo: A large concretion of minerals or metals.

properties.Name: Isola Rossa 2
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/678/1/trovati-due-relitti-nei-fondali-del-golfo-dellasinara.html
properties.Comments: A Roman wreck found during a deep marine survey in 2007.

properties.Name: Isola Rossa 3
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/678/1/trovati-due-relitti-nei-fondali-del-golfo-dellasinara.html
properties.Comments: The second ancient wreck found during a deep marine survey in 2007.
properties.Other cargo: A concretion probably of metal

properties.Name: L'Asinara 1
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/678/1/trovati-due-relitti-nei-fondali-del-golfo-dellasinara.html
properties.Comments: A very deep wreck examined by ROV in 2007.

properties.Name: Cala Reale
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 460; P. Spanu, Atti del Convegno Nazionale di Archaologia Subacquea. Anzio 1996, (1997), 109-119.          http://members.xoom.it/crasa/calareal.htm
properties.Comments: A cargo of 5 types of mainly Spanish fish sauce amphorae found in 1995.
properties.Other cargo: A shipment of glass paste tesserae accompanied the main cargo of amphorae.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A coin manufactured by the mint of Rome between 364 and 367 during the reign of Valens.

properties.Name: Bera
properties.Reference: Berges, 1970; Corsi-Sciallano and Liou, 1985:153; Liou, 1987b: 284
properties.Comments: A substantial cargo that covered an area of at least 12 x 7m.

properties.Name: Rena Maiore
properties.Reference: G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 104
properties.Other cargo: Lead ingots, many of them stamped.

properties.Name: Sud Lavezzi 5
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2005, 94-96.
properties.Comments: The site covers an area 30 x 15m with a variety of scattered remains but no obvious principal cargo suggesting wheat or some other organic material.
properties.Other cargo: Tegulae; ceramics, terra sigillata plates from N Italy etc.
properties.Hull remains: About 20m of the hull seems farily well preserved from what seems to have been a substantial ship. Fragments of lead plates (sheathing?), a bronze nail.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A Gauloise 5 amphora.
properties.Ship equipment: Six to eight iron anchors; a piece of the pump.

properties.Name: Lavezzi A (1)
properties.Reference: B. Liou, Archaeonutica 10 (1990), 125- 155
properties.Other cargo: At least 7 lead ingots and 18 copper ingots.

properties.Name: Cavallo A
properties.Reference: C. Carreras Montfort and P. Berni Millet in Rivet and Sciallano (eds), Vivre, Produire et Echanger: Reflets Mediterraneans. Melanges offerts a Bernard Liou (2002), 359-369

properties.Name: Cavallo 4
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 77
properties.Comments: An area 20 x 10m of scattered Medieval ceramics.

properties.Name: Sud-Perduto A
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique  2005, 94
properties.Comments: Originally seen as a mound of amphorae 2m high in 1980, the site is now spread out  measuring 25 x 15m.

properties.Name: Est Perduto 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique  2005, 96-97
properties.Comments: A site measuring 20 x 12m of various amphorae and ceramics.
properties.Other cargo: A large amount of Campanian ceramics - plates, bowls and cups.

properties.Name: Est-Perduto 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique  2005, 93; C. Carreras Montfort and P. Berni Millet in Rivet and Sciallano (eds), Vivre, Produire et Echanger: Reflets Mediterraneans. Melanges offerts a Bernard Liou (2002), 359-369
properties.Comments: A much pillaged site of Dr 2-4 amphorae.

properties.Name: Ratino 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1993, 62
properties.Comments: A cargo of Dr 2-4 amphorae.

properties.Name: Margherita di Savoia
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2004/news0407.htm#margherita                                                       http://www.archeomar.it/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=32&Itemid=47
properties.Comments: The remains of a hull and unspecified ceramics mark the site discovered in 2004.
properties.Hull remains: At least 9 beams and numerous other parts of planking can be seen. Mortise and tenon construction, many iron nails also found on the site.

properties.Name: Les Moines 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 75
properties.Comments: A rare (for French waters) site of Medieval ceramics.
properties.Other cargo: Some decorated fragments of Arabic ceramics and tableware, some from Pisa.

properties.Name: Les Moines 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1993, 61; Bilan Scientifique 1999, 75-76
properties.Comments: A cargo of amphorae badly broken up and concreted amongst rocks over an area 20 x 15m.

properties.Name: Les Moines 3
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 77
properties.Comments: Scattered remains of a cargo of Gauloise 4 amphorae.
properties.Other cargo: Three lead ingots (type Domergue 1)were found nearby.

properties.Name: Porto Novo
properties.Reference:
H. Bernard et al JRA 11 (1998), 53-81;  J. Chiapetti and H. Bernard, Bilan Scientifique 1992, 63; R. Mazeran in E. Rieth (ed.), Méditerranée antique (1998), 135-138.
http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/archeosm/fr/
properties.Comments: A cargo of unfinished marble and stone-working tools.
properties.Marble type: Over an area of 15m x 7m, four column fragments between 2.2m and 4.8m long with a diameter of 1.5m; five blocks, one of which is large at 23.3 tons, all in an unfinished state from Luna . A total weight is estimated at 138 tons. Some badly finished slabs of veneer of coloured marble, from a variety of sources, Chemtou, Teos, Chios and Carystos,  possibly left over from previous journeys. Black and white quartz from Egypt. A large number of sets of stone-working tools.
properties.Hull remains: A few iron nails, bronze tubing and four bronze nails. Estimated length of ship 25m from the lay out of the marble. Lead sheathing.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Fragments of pottery; 110 fishing weights; at least 3 mirrors, a bronze strigil; bronze vases; a decorated sword and buckle. These suggest the presence of military or official (including female) personnel. A coin of Tiberius AD 27.

properties.Name: La Vacca, Iles Cerbicales
properties.Reference: H. Bernard, Bilan Scientifique 1999, 77
properties.Other cargo: Millstone.

properties.Name: Calanque de Conca
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1992, 58
properties.Comments: Discovered in the 1960s and re-examined in the 1990s, this was a cargo of dolia (but interestingly without the usual accompaniament of Dr 2-4 amphorae).
properties.Other cargo: A large amount of fragments of jugs.

properties.Name: Marina di Fiori
properties.Reference: H. Bernard, Bilan Scientifique 1993, 60-61; Bilan Scientifique 1994, 63; Bilan Scientifique 1995, 69; Bilan Scientifique 1996, 113' Etienne and Mayet, 2000, 245, no 45
properties.Comments: Spread over an area 17m sq, an interesting wreck of blocks of minerals as well as amphorae with hitherto unknown stamps. Evidently there had been a serious fire on board (blackened sherds and melted resin) which probably led to its demise.
properties.Other cargo: A secondary cargo of blocks of minerals, never found on a wreck before. Some are of clay and are stamped MACILI and VENU.
properties.Hull remains: Iron nails and part of the cabin including tegulae stamped with L.HEREN (IUS) and MARI.
properties.Ship equipment: Part of a pipe

properties.Name: Banc du Benedetto
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1997, 86

properties.Name: Cala Rossa
properties.Reference: H. Bernard and F. Cibecchini, Bilan Scientifique 2004, 92-93; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 99; F. Cibecchini et al, Archaeologia Maritima Mediterranea 2006, 13-41
properties.Comments: Discovered in 1962 and re-examined in the early 2000s, the site covers an area of 65m sq. NB Date change since Parker.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A large amount of common ware and cooking pottery (jars, ollae, pots etc.)

properties.Name: Olmeto
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 77
properties.Comments: A badly preserved cargo of amphorae.

properties.Name: Porto Pollo 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 75
properties.Other cargo: Small iron ingots.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A bronze coin.

properties.Name: Pointe Cacalu
properties.Reference: H. Alfonsi, Bilan Scientifique 1997, 86; Bilan Scientifique1999, 74-75; Bilan Scientifique 2000, 83-84; Bilan Scientifique 2001, 85
properties.Comments: A badly broken up cargo of Dr 1B amphorae.
properties.Other cargo: Oil lamps including Dressel-Lamboglia type 3 classic.
properties.Hull remains: Some remains show that the ship was built of oak, ash and pie. Iron and copper nails.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Part of some bronze scales
properties.Ship equipment: A complete pulley made of beech, oak and ash

properties.Name: L'Isolella
properties.Reference: H. Alfonsi and P. Gandolfo, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 10 (1991), 199-207
properties.Comments: A cargo of tiles.
properties.Other cargo: Tegulae (57 complete and 388 fragments) and imbricae (56 complete and 80 fragments).
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A Dr 20 amphora, a carpenter's pick-axe and a small axe

properties.Name: Porticcio
properties.Reference: H. Alfonsi, Bilan Scientifique 2001, 84; Bilan Scientifique 2002, 79; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 99; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 93.                http://www.wmaker.net/ARASM/index.php?action=article&id_article=43913                                                                                                                                       http://lci.tf1.fr/science/histoire/2004-11/decouverte-exceptionnelle-dans-eaux-corses-5518919.html
properties.Comments: A hugely varied cargo  - eleven types of amphorae including Kapitän I and II, Africano I and II, Dr. 20, Gauloise, Almagro 50 and 51c, Béltran 72 and Egyptian - glass and 2 marble statues.
properties.Marble type: Two 2m high marble statues representing the Roman Emperor Philip 1 of Arabia (ruled AD 244-249) and his wife Marcia Otacilia, in fragments but weighing about 600kg each.
properties.Other cargo: African coarse ware and millstones. Sheets of glass and glass objects with a total weight of at least 230kg.
properties.Hull remains: A 25cm wide section of the keel  as well as  pieces of frames and planking.

properties.Name: Sanguinaires
properties.Reference: H. Alfonsi and P. Gandolfo, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 13 (1997), 35-74;                                 http://www.wmaker.net/ARASM/index.php?action=article&id_article=43913
properties.Comments: A mixed cargo of amphorae, ceramics, glass and ingots.
properties.Other cargo: Coarse ware, fineware, red and black-glazed pottery. Attic lamps. Small copper ingots and millstones as ballast. At least 550kg of glass, both manufactured and unmanufactured.
properties.Hull remains: None of the hull itself, only some copper nails and fragments of lead sheathing.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A bronze coin of Ptolemy Euergetes (246-221BC) or Ptolemy IV (211-204BC).

properties.Name: Torre Flavia C ?
properties.Reference: http://www.gatc.it/ritagli/torreflavianave.htm
properties.Comments: Dated by Arretine ware to first years of 1st c AD - Augustan; assumed to be different from Torre Flavia B (Parker 1158). Some interesting shipboard items, well preserved in the mud.
properties.Hull remains: Fairly well preserved, with an estimated size of 20m length and 5 m width.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Cooking pots and tableware including pans and pots of various types and sizes, jars, cups and plates all of decent quality. Some of them are certainly Arezzo production as indicated by the pottery with Arezzo stamps imprinted on them. Particularly valuable are some trappings of a back of a bed, decorated with carvings and moldings, culminating with the head of a duck, whose empty slots in the head and beak indicateng that originally it was embellished with colored stones . Even more unusual was the discovery of a wooden box covered with a tiny lock of bronze. Surprisingly it was found that it contained capsules of coriander and cumin. Both substances were widely used in medical treatment. In particular, the coriander and cumin were used to treat stomach ailments, ever present on board an ancient ship
properties.Ship equipment: A dozen wooden disks with holes in their centre  were found in the middle of the ship. They belonged to the internal workings of a manually operated hydraulic pump that sucked water from the bilge.

properties.Name: Capo Linaro
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 459; Petriaggi, Naxos 1997.
properties.Comments: Dolia.
properties.Hull remains: The hull is about 5m long and in good condition.

properties.Name: Punta del Diavolo
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html          area 1 site 9
properties.Comments: Also known as shipwreck B of the Tre Senghe, a cargo of stone difficult to date due to the lack of ceramic evidence.
properties.Marble type: A cargo of stone (marble??) comprising of blocks, slabs, small columns and pillars. It is covered in in concretions which hinders exact definition of the material, but is i  its original stacked position

properties.Name: Tre Senghe
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html           area 1 site 8
properties.Comments: Shipwreck A of the Tre Senghe (shipwreck B = Punta del Diavolo).

properties.Name: Caprara
properties.Reference: http://www.archeomar.it/templates/archeomar/atlante/player_atlante_en.html        site 128  area 1
properties.Comments: A Roman wreck from the island of Caprara, Tremiti Islands. Although there are few amphorae, they are close to the piles of tiles suggesting they were part of the cargo.
properties.Other cargo: Two piles of tiles still in stacked position. The tiles have a form typical of the Roman period, with the dimensions of approximately 40 cm x 30 cm, with a flat surface and raised edges on the longer two sides. The concretions which cover this material mean it is impossible to identify any stamps.

properties.Name: Cala del Diavolo
properties.Reference: http://www.sportesport.it/wrecksTI002.htm
properties.Comments: A Roman trade vessel carrying a cargo of wine in Lamboglia 2 amphorae, and black Campanian pottery.
properties.Other cargo: Black Campanian pottery.
properties.Ship equipment: A beautiful encrusted iron anchor was recovered from the wreck

properties.Name: Montalto di Castro
properties.Reference: B. Davidde, IJNA 31 (2002), 84
properties.Comments: A cargo of amphorae that has been covered with sheets of metal and fibre glass to protect it until excavation.

properties.Name: Palagruza B (Pupak Reef)
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 62; M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A badly looted site of a cargo of amphorae and pottery.
