properties.Other cargo: Pottery, numerous sherds of clay mortaria and, uniquely for the Adriatic,  chamber pots (lasanua). South Italic services of 'orlo bifido' dishes with plates/lids and Pompeian red ware plates were also found.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A massive profiled bronze rod of indefinite function

properties.Name: Mala Palagruza
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 39
properties.Comments: A heavily looted site of a dolia cargo.
properties.Ship equipment: Remains of an iron anchor and a lead anchor stock.

properties.Name: Boka Kotorska 2
properties.Reference: J. Royal, INA Annual 2008 26-28; http://www.rpmnautical.org/bokakotorska2.htm
properties.Comments: This Roman ship was found over 2km off shore , covering an area 20 x 17m, with many of its amphorae in their original stacked position.

properties.Name: Boka Kotorska  1
properties.Reference: J Royal, INA Annual 2008, 26-28; http://www.rpmnautical.org/bokakotorska1.htm
properties.Comments: A cargo of tiles comprise a large shipment on what must have been a vessel of significant dimensions now spread over an area 25 x 7m.
properties.Other cargo: Pan tiles and cover tiles are in several stacks, many of which are now postitioned vertically. The pan tiles measure c 65 x 45 cm with flanges angled at 90 degrees and are characteristic of Roman manufacture during the Imperial period.

properties.Name: Supetric
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 69
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck of tegulae and imbrices.
properties.Other cargo: A large quantity of tegulae and imbrices suggests a shipwreck.

properties.Name: Port Vendres 11
properties.Reference: S. Got Castellvi and M. Amandry, Bilan Scientifique 2005, 33-34
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: 1100 coins in 3 portions of 471, 249 and 62 pieces, plus 249 scattered coins in various states of preservation. They had probably been contained in material or leather bags which have since disappeared. They were not great value coins so may have belonged to one of the crew. They can be dated to AD 270-274.

properties.Name: Redoute Bear 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2000, 40; Bilan Scientifique 2001, 41; Bilan Scientifique 2002, 38-39
properties.Comments: The ship was about 15m-17m long and 6m wide.
properties.Hull remains: 192 copper nails
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Campanian ware, Catalan ware

properties.Name: Port Vendres 9 (Redoute Bear 2)
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2000, 40-1; Bilan Scientifique 2001, 4; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 36
properties.Comments: A site comprising 5 layers of which 2 seem to be a shipwreck of the first half of the C5th AD.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Glass ware, eastern Med ceramics
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast stones (siliceous sandstone)

properties.Name: Port Vendres C/ 3
properties.Reference: M. Jezegou, Bilan Scientifique 2005, 41
properties.Other cargo: A small amount of glass tableware.
properties.Hull remains: Some well preserved sections showing mortise and tenon construction along with some ligature work cf Cap Bear 3 wreck

properties.Name: Port Vendres D
properties.Dating: end C1st BC- beg C1st AD
properties.Reference: C. Carreras Montfort and P. Berni Millet in Rivet and Sciallano (eds), Vivre, Produire et Echanger: Reflets Mediterraneans. Melanges offerts a Bernard Liou (2002), 359-369; M. Jezegou, Bilan Scientifique 2005, 42

properties.Name: Cavtat 2
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: Largest cargo  found in the Adriatic now protected by an iron cage.

properties.Name: Supetar
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 66  and in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A dolia shipwreck although there are no hull remains.

properties.Name: Elba
properties.Reference: http://www.archaeogate.org/subacquea/article/112/1/relitto-profondo-dallelba-di-mario-galasso.html
properties.Comments: A large cargo ship of Spanish amphorae seen as a 45m long mound, accidentally discovered during a dive with a mini-sub.

properties.Name: Cape Borova
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: Finds from this site are known from illegal exports confiscated by customs officers!
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Parts of a loutherion.

properties.Name: Veliki Skolj
properties.Reference: D. Vrsalović, PhD thesis (unpublished, 1979), 248-9; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no.81.
properties.Marble type: 15 basins or unfinished sarcophagi with lids.
properties.Other cargo: Sherds of Eastern coarse ware two-handled dishes, oinochoe.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A piece of Beltran 2A amphora and some fragments of a Dr. 6A amphora.

properties.Name: Vratnicka
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 90
properties.Comments: A cargo of different-sized Dr 2-4 was found.

properties.Name: Cape Tiha
properties.Reference: M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A looted wreck, although dispersed finds are known from private collections.

properties.Name: Okuklje Cove
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 50
properties.Comments: A 'problematical' find, reflecting the widespread vertical distance of the cargo of probable Dr 6 amphorae.

properties.Name: Punta Vecchia 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2003, 96; Bilan Scientifique  2004, 87; Bilan Scientifique  2005, 88
properties.Comments: Scattered sherds from Spanish amphorae.

properties.Name: Maharac Cape
properties.Reference: D. Vrsalović, PhD thesis (unpublished; 1979), 247; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no.38.
properties.Other cargo: Eastern coarse ware pottery of biconical dishes and trefoil mouth jugs.

properties.Name: Jakljan Island
properties.Reference: M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no.21.
properties.Marble type: Three sarcophagi with lids.

properties.Name: Kopiste
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 29, and in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A cargo of amphorae that was well preserved on first inspection in 1993 but devestated by 1995.

properties.Name: Mrcara
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 47

properties.Name: Golfo di Porto Azzurro
properties.Reference: http://www.elba-vacanze.net/pagina.php?ling=i&rif_pagina=127&rif_argo=69&rif_tema=2&rif_cap=&rif_cap=41&p=0#
properties.Comments: An unexplored Roman wreck with a cargo of tubi fittili per condutture.

properties.Name: Erbalunga
properties.Reference: H. Bernard, Bilan Scientifique 1997, 87
properties.Comments: A single amphora full of 21,000 Roman coins.
properties.Other cargo: 32kg of medium and small-sized coins dated to the end of the reign of Constantine I and the end of the C4th AD. The amphora was a Byzantine Keay XXV.

properties.Name: Lastovo B (Saplun)
properties.Reference: M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A complete cargo of 150 amphorae.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A loutherion

properties.Name: Lastovska
properties.Region: Mljet Island, north west of Dubrovnik
properties.Reference: D. Vrsalović, Istraživanja i Zaštita Podmorških Arheoloskih Spomenika u S.R. Hrvatskoj (1974), 53 and 240; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 35.
properties.Comments: Amphorae of mostly transitional La.2/Dr.6A but also some Rhodian imperial.

properties.Name: Glavat Islet
properties.Region: NW side of Mljet island, north west of Dubrovnik.
properties.Reference: M. Jurisić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 9.
properties.Comments: Mostly Lamboglia  2/Dr. 6A amphorae but also sherds of Dr. 2-4 Coan and Rhodian.
properties.Ship equipment: In the shallow part of the site, there is a small number of reddish ballast stone slabs.

properties.Name: Cape Glavat/Mljet B
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 10
properties.Comments: Dating of this wreck may be adjusted to 40-80 AD on the basis of the Italian terra sigillata Drag, 24/25?
properties.Other cargo: Southern Italian pottery, 'orlo bifido' dishes with the plates/ lids (more than 500) and 15 Pompeian red plates. Great quantities of rough glass clumps.
properties.Hull remains: Well preserved parts of the hull were found (7m long).
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Italian terra sigillata Drag, 24/25 bearing the stamps PESCECLE and C.IUL.FIR (Pescenius Clemens and Caius Iulius Firmus) and  some eastern ware Five oil lamps and 2 glass vessels were of western origin. A few necks of Cretan amphorae, a number of  ECW pottery (mugs, jugs, dishes and lids) were of eastern origin.
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock of  so-called movable model with astragali relief, 6 braces and part of a bronze steelyard were found.

properties.Name: Toscana Cala del Barbiere
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 460; G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 50
properties.Comments: Discovered by Lamboglia in the 1970s but excavated in the 90s. A large ship with an interesting cargo from diverse parts of the Mediterranean.
properties.Hull remains: Mortise and tenons join the hull planks and are reinforced with nails.

properties.Name: Sant'Andrea A
properties.Reference: http://www.legambientearcipelagotoscano.it/localmente/storia/archeologia.htm

properties.Name: Sant'Andrea B
properties.Reference: http://www.legambientearcipelagotoscano.it/localmente/storia/archeologia.htm

properties.Name: Marciano Marina
properties.Reference: http://www.legambientearcipelagotoscano.it/localmente/storia/scoperte.htm
properties.Comments: Other cargo and the hull are probably still buried underneath, and the ship is estimated to have been between 20 and 30m long.

properties.Name: Lirica
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 36
properties.Comments: A cargo of Dr 6A amphorae.

properties.Name: Arles IV
properties.Reference: http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/archeosm/fr/fr-medit-antiq.htm             Pomey et al 1992; L. Long, Bilan Scientifique 1993, 30-31; Long 1997, p. 79-82
properties.Comments: The site measures 30 m by 10m and was investigated in the early 1990s by submarine, 74km from the mouth of the Rhone. The cargo comprised several layers of amphorae, possibly 1000-2000 in total, of 3 different types - a large group holding fish sauce in the middle, surrounded by oil amphorae with small, flat-bottomed amphorae at each end.
properties.Other cargo: Pottery and copper ingots.
properties.Hull remains: Probably in good condition under the cargo of amphorae
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock and  an iron anchor.

properties.Name: Perelli
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2003/news0307.htm#perelli
properties.Comments: An early Imperial wreck of amphorae and other ceramics.
properties.Other cargo: Ceramics?

properties.Name: La Jaume-Garde B
properties.Reference: P. Pomey, Bilan scientifique du Département des recherches archéologiques sous-marines (1993), 44
properties.Hull remains: The construction was mixed with a combination of ligatures and more traditional mortise and tenon (cf Tour Fondue 1, Barthelemy B, Plane 1, Cap Bear 3, Roche Fouras, Baie de l'Amitie, Cap del Vol, Cavaliere and Port la Nautique).

properties.Name: Viganj (Sv. Ivan promontory)
properties.Reference: Z. Rapanić, Arheoloski Pregled 14 (1972), 79-80; D. Vrsalović, Istraživanja i Zaštita Podmorških Arheoloskih Spomenika u S.R. Hrvatskoj (1974), 39 and 239-40, figs. 2, 30 and 67; J. Istenić, Diadora 10 (1988), 99-110; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no.73; M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A large but now looted cargo of ECW pottery.
properties.Other cargo: Estimated 50,000 pieces of Eastern coarse ware pottery, much looted, including bowls, dishes, trefoil mouth jugs, pots, lids, platters with profiled rim, braziers etc. More than 200 pieces were raised.
properties.Hull remains: Hull is well preserved.

properties.Name: Bugho I
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1994, 59; Bilan Scientifique 2004, 88
properties.Comments: The first wreck found in Corsica to contain Dr 1B amphorae.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Common pottery, part of a musical instrument, a unicum.
properties.Ship equipment: Lead sounding weights

properties.Name: Karantunic
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 24
properties.Comments: A cargo of amphorae, probably Dr 6A.

properties.Name: Bagaud C
properties.Reference: L. Long and G. Volpe, Bilan Scientifique 1997, 73-74;  Bilan Scientifique 1998, 45-46; Bilan Scientifique 1999, 63-64
properties.Comments: A cargo of Gauloise 4 amphorae first discovered in the 1960s and recently re-examined. Although only several amphorae have been found, they probably numbered several hundred originally.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A few fragments of ceramics including a cup, Hayes 196, and a pot Hayes 197. A terracotta pipe may be left over from a previous load, possibly belonging to a heating system.

properties.Name: La Plage d'Argent 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 60
properties.Comments: Although this is a site comprising objects from various eras that has been damaged and pillaged, there does seem to be a wreck datable to the Roman Republic .

properties.Name: La Plage d'Argent 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 62-63

properties.Name: Marine de Tollare
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1992, 59

properties.Name: Bagaud B
properties.Comments: A cargo of small tin and iron ingots weighing 2-3kg each.
properties.Other cargo: Tin and iron ingots, some marked. According to one round inscription, the merchants were Celts, specifically Hypocelts who were assembled by a Greek named Heracleides for the coomercial exploration of tin.

properties.Name: Tour d'Agnello 1
properties.Reference: G. Leroy de La Briere, Bilan Scientifique  2005, 88
properties.Comments: A much pillaged site.

properties.Name: La Palud 1
properties.Reference: L. Long and G. Volpe, Bilan Scientifique 1993, 46-47; Bilan Scientifique 1994, 48; Bilan Scientifique 1995, 53;  in M. Bonifay (ed.) Fouilles a Marseille. Les mobiliers (Ier- VII siecles ap. J.-C.), (1998), 317-42S; M. Bonifay et al, in L. Rivet and M. Sciallano (eds). Vivre, Produire et Echanger: Reflets Mediterraneans. Melanges offerts a Bernard Liou (2002), 198-199; S. Kingsley, Barbarian Seas: Late Rome to Islam (Perpilus, 2004), 41.
properties.Comments: An 18,000 litre cargo of North African and Eastern wine amphorae covering 60-80 sq m.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A unique find was a rectangular wooden box that once held secure round round copper or bronze weights from a merchant's balance. The designs of the weights are still preserved in the soft grain of the wood, so that a Byzantine emperor (of the period AD 527-28) staring out of the box is all that remains of the weights today. Fragments of African sigillata Hayes type 99 and 103B, as well as Late Roman C ware, type Hayes 3E.

properties.Name: La Palud 2
properties.Reference: L. Long and G. Volpe, Bilan Scientifique 1994, 48-49
properties.Comments: An archaic shipwreck carrying dozens of Massiliot amphorae, cf Dattier and Bon Porte wrecks.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Some Massiliot coarseware

properties.Name: Pointe Lequin 1A
properties.Reference: P. Pomey et al 1987-88, 32-35; L. Long et al., Bilan Scientifique 1990, Bilan Scientifique 1992, 50 Bilan Scientifique 1993, 45-46; L. Long and M. Rival, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 16 (2007), 98-114.
properties.Comments: The wreck of a ship carrying a cargo of wine and fine tableware from the Aegean.
properties.Other cargo: Small bronze statue of a helmeted soldier; a large amount of Attic coarse ware and B2 cups (about 2,500 pieces) - decorated with scenes of  battle, mythology and daily life; oil lamps
properties.Hull remains: Part of the hull and keel? with mortise and tenons, 7.5 cm pieces of strakes. Two pieces of wood which are thought to be part of the rudder, cf Grand Ribaud F wreck .

properties.Name: Le Miladou
properties.Reference: M. Dumontier and J.-P. Joncheray, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 10 (1991), 109-174.
properties.Comments: A small ship, 15m long, carrying a single layer of about 250 Italian amphorae that have spread over an area 35m sq.
properties.Hull remains: Nine metres of poorly preserved remains show a classic construction. The keel was made of pine while many species of wood were used for the frames and planks including fig!
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock weighing 82kg. Two lead pipes, 1.6m and 1.49m long.

properties.Name: Sveti Andrija (Svetac island)
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 70; M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A much looted wreck of western Mediterranean amphorae.

properties.Name: Le Grand Ribaud F (A??)
properties.Reference: Les Etrusques : un voyage interrompu, by Bernard George; L. Long, P. Pomey and J-C Sourisseau, Les Etrusques en Mer (2000); L. Long et al, Bilan Scientifique 2000, 68-71; Bilan Scientifique 2001, 74-44; Bilan Scientifique 2002, 68-70; L. Long, Cahiers d'Archeologie 14 (2002), 5-40; L. Long and M. Rival, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 16 (2007), 98-114.         http://www.abc.se/~pa/uwa/wreckmed.htm
properties.Comments: Etruscan wreck found by DRASSM and Comex in 2000 near Giens, France. Investigated by Luc Long in 2000 and 2001, using divers, mini sub and ROV. Several amphoras and bronze drinking bowls, and black-figure ceramics, were recovered. The ship is ca 30 m long, 7 m wide, loaded with 700-800 amphoras. The amphoras are made of clay from the Pyrgi area in Etruria.  The largest Etruscan wreck found so far.
properties.Other cargo: Etruscan and Greek black-figure ceramics and bronze drinking bowls.
properties.Hull remains: The lower hull is perfectly preserved under sand and sediment, including the rudder (cf Pointe Lequin 1A). False-tenon construction, with framing timbers (fastened by iron nails) which retained the forms of the frames found in stitched ships such as the Bon-Porte and Jules-Verne wrecks - points to local Greek construction.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: The bottom of a cup inscribed with a graffito which may be Greek. Etruscan amphorae type Py 5, Greek amphorae; mortars; an iron knife; .

properties.Name: Heliopolis A
properties.Reference: J.-P. Joncheray,  Bilan Scientifique 1992, 51; Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 13 (1997), 137-164; M. Bonifay et al, in L. Rivet and M. Sciallano (eds). Vivre, Produire et Echanger: Reflets Mediterraneans. Melanges offerts a Bernard Liou (2002), 195-196.
properties.Comments: A small ship holding an estimated capacity of only 720 amphorae, most of which had already disappeared by the time this site was properly excavated.
properties.Hull remains: One of the latest dated ships to be sheathed in lead although not much remains. Some nails. Probable length of 14m.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Coarseware, a copper dish, fragments of lead.

properties.Name: La Giraglia
properties.Reference: M. Sciallano, Bilan Scientifique 1995, 60; Bilan Scientifique 1997, 81; Bilan Scientifique 1998, 56; Bilan Scientifique 1999, 70-72; Etienne & Mayet 2000, 245 no. 44; S. Marlier and P. Sibella, IJNA 31 (2002), 161-171; M Sciallano and S. Marlier, Archaeonautica 15 (2008), 113-152.
properties.Comments: Discovered in 1992, spread over 200m sq, a  cargo of dolia and amphorae, very badly wrecked probably due to the dolia rolling out of place as the ship sank. A very similar cargo to that of Chretienne H.
properties.Other cargo: Six fragments of Aretine ware, one with a stampTHALI. Four fragments of blue-green glass from 2 plates and 2 cups.
properties.Hull remains: 7m long by 2m wide, 26 frames but no trace of the keel. The ship was probably about 20m long and was of classic hull first construction, built from oak, elm and beech, ash and fir.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Two miniscule fragments of oil lamps, some fineware fragments, 5 nuts and 8 noisettes; several Gauloise 4 or 5 fragments.
properties.Ship equipment: Pump remains, lead anchor stock

properties.Name: La Tour Fondue
properties.Reference: B. Dangreaux, Bilan Scientifique 1993, 44-45; Bilan Scientifique 1994, 47; Bilan Scientifique 1995, 51-52; Bilan Scientifique 1996, 89-90; Bilan Scientifique 1997, 57-59
properties.Comments: NB Date change since Parker. A local ship carrying amphorae and Massiliot ceramics.
properties.Other cargo: Massiliot ceramics - cups and millstones.
properties.Hull remains: Built with oak and pine, sections survive that show that the ship was partially constructed with ligatures as well as by moritse and tenon cf Cavaliere wreck.
properties.Ship equipment: An anchor, 4kg of ballast stones

properties.Name: Komiza
properties.Reference: M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no.27.
properties.Comments: Completely looted site with sherds of Egyptian (Somalian) amphorae.

properties.Name: Host B
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000) no. 18
properties.Comments: A cargo of rare Dr 35-36 amphorae, allegedly as there are no illustrations.

properties.Name: Veli Porat
properties.Reference: M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A looted cargo of amphorae with some cabin ware of Eastern Sigilatta A - the only example from the Adriatic.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Eastern Sigilatta A pottery.

properties.Name: Capraia Etruscan 2004
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2004/news0411.htm#capraia
properties.Comments: One of two ancient wrecks discovered in 2004 300m off the island of Capraia.  No details given about the cargo except that there were 'various relics'.

properties.Name: Capraia Roman 2004
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2004/news0411.htm#capraia
properties.Comments: One of two ancient wrecks discovered in 2004 300m off the island of Capraia. No details given about the cargo except that there were 'various relics'.

properties.Name: Le Formiche di Capraia
properties.Reference: G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 50           http://www.promare.org/project_capraiashipwreck.html
properties.Comments: The  60 x 40 m site is extremely well preserved possibly due to a thick layer of seagrass. The absence of an amphora mound suggests that the main cargo may have been perishable, or else the main part of the wreck is still to be found.
properties.Other cargo: Black-glazed pottery from central Italy, including plates, cups and bowls.
properties.Hull remains: Several copper and iron nails testify to the presence of wooden planks in this spot on the seafloor
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Some diagnostic artefacts such as a bronze Roman coin with representation of a ship's bow. dated to the first half of the second century B.C.,  one black-glazed guttus, and a well-preserved oil-lamp  were found also during the 2009 campaign. Two lead fishing-weights (one left on the seafloor), found close to the bronze coin and in association with a little bronze blade might represent evidence of an ancient fishing net lost on this site, with the necessary tools ready to clean the newly-caught fish

properties.Name: Ouest Embiez 1
properties.Reference:
D. Foy and M.- P. Jézégou, Bilan scientifique du Département des recherches archéologiques sous-marines (1995), 61-62; ibid.((2000), 65-66; ibid. (2001), 71-72; ibid. (2002), 65-67; ibid. (2003), 86-90; ibid. (2004), 76-82; ibid. (2005), 76-81;  D. Foy and M.- P. Jézégou in E. Rieth (ed.), Méditerranée antique (1998), 121-134; D. Foy and S. Fontaine, Poseidons Reich XI 17.9.2006, p.18
http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/archeosm/fr/
http://www2.cnrs.fr/presse/journal/1318.htm?print=1
properties.Comments: A secondary cargo of mixed amphorae, eleven Dr. 2-4 from Italy, eight from Gaul, two from Spain, six Agora F65-6 from Asia Minor and two Africano 1B. 30 in total, though some of these (Gaul and Spain) may have been for onboard use.
properties.Other cargo: Principal cargo of colourless glass: irregular blocks of very good quality raw glass up to 25kg each with a total of at least 10 tons stacked in the centre of the boat. More than fifteen fragments of sheet glass, all rectangular except one circular piece with a diameter of 43cm (very rare). At least 2000 pieces of glassware, the majority of which are cylindrical goblets, with different types of bases, stacked together. The sheets of glass were definitely made on the Syrian-Palestinian coast between Acre and Haifa which was famous for its glass production (Pliny NH 36.45; Josephus BJ 11.188; Strabo 16,758). The other glass could have come from any Mediterranean area.
properties.Hull remains: Eleven ribs of 2m long, other fragments including two strakes. The ship was no more than 15m long.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Coarseware (Eastern Sigillata A and African) and food remnants including animal bones, snail shells and olive stones.
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast stones.

properties.Name: Krava
properties.Reference: N. Cambi in Amphores Romains et Histoire Economique, Dix Ans de Rechereches (Siena, 1986) 1989, 323-5; M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: The earliest known wreck in the Adriatic.
properties.Other cargo: Grindstones and handmills

properties.Name: Grand Rouveau 2
properties.Reference: A. and J.-P. Joncheray, Bilan Scientifique 1997, 56; Bilan Scientifique 1999, 57-58; Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 15 (2004), 119-134.
properties.Comments: A cargo of tiles dispersed between two great rock masses over 15m, possibly one of the earliest in Antiquity.
properties.Other cargo: Tiles, between 100 and 300 imbrices and probably as many tegulae.
properties.Hull remains: None.

properties.Name: Cap Benat B/ Cap Benat 2
properties.Reference: J-P Joncheray, Bilan Scientifique 1992, 51; Bilan Scientifique 1993, 48-49;  Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 13 (1997), 97-119 .
properties.Comments: There are a few anomolies regarding this small ship that held 3 or 4 dolia eg. why did one of the dolia contain bones?
properties.Hull remains: A classic construction, only 4m survives, including sections of the keel and frames. Probably only 8m long
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Coarseware, Campanian A and C ware.
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast stones made up of different rocks, and Massiliot, Dr 1A and Dr 1C amphora fragments.

properties.Name: Plage d'Arles 5
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan Scientifique 1996, 77-8; Bilan Scientifique 2000, 58-59.
properties.Comments: A cargo of Gallic terra sigillata of which 3 pieces have been brought to the surface.
properties.Other cargo: Sigillata from La Graufesenque, some stamped, that dates the wreck to the period of Claudius/Vespasian.

properties.Name: Duboka Cove
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: An oval amphora inscribed with BDEUNOR points towards the presence of African merchants managing the shipment.

properties.Name: Anse de Montfort
properties.Reference: Etienne & Mayet 2000, 241 no. 22

properties.Name: Anse de Montfort 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1995, 35;
properties.Comments: One of several ancient wrecks found in very shallow waters in the northern section of L'Etang de Bages-Sigean, also known as Anse de Montfort.

properties.Name: Anse de Montfort 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1995, 35;
properties.Comments: One of several ancient wrecks found in very shallow waters in the northern section of L'Etang de Bages-Sigean, also known as Anse de Montfort. This deposit of amphorae carrying traces of soot along with blackened fragments of wood suggests  a ship that sank due to fire.

properties.Name: Lardier 4
properties.Reference: A. and J.-P. Joncheray, Bilan Scientifique 1995, 58; Bilan Scientifique 1997, 75-76; Bilan Scientifique 1998, 50; Bilan Scientifique 1999, 65; Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 15 (2004), 73-118.
properties.Comments: A small cargo of local tiles.
properties.Other cargo: Nine rows of tegulae in 2 layers and imbrices in the residual spaces. A large amount of pottery typical of the lower Argens valley (Rivet form 17).
properties.Hull remains: Twelve strakes and 9 frames, as well as part of the keel show a typical mortise and tenon construction of a small (12m) ship.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A Massiliot amphora, an iron stove (a 'foculus', cf Barthelemy B and Cap Benat wrecks) and kitchen utensils; 2 ceramic pipettes, small scales and a touchstone
properties.Ship equipment: Twenty-five rigging rings

properties.Name: La Ciotat C
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2001, 64-68
properties.Comments: A site measuring 16.5 x 3.5m of a cargo of Dr 1A amphorae.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Thirty fragments of coarseware including 'ollae'.

properties.Name: Calanque Devenson 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 51-52.
properties.Comments: The site covers an area of 20m and the amphorae were fairly broken up.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: The body of a Lamboglia 2 amphora.

properties.Name: Calanque Devenson 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 52.
properties.Comments: A fairly widespread wreck site of Dr 20 amphorae.

properties.Name: Pakleni/ Izmetište
properties.Reference: B. Ilakovac, Diadora 4 (1968), 183-202; M. Orlić and M. Jurišić, Obavijesti Hrvatska Arheološka Drustva 18 no. 1 (1986), 43; J. Istenić, Diadora 10 (1988), 99-110; Parker (1992), 773; V. Gaffney et al., Projekt Jadranski otoci, Arheološka baština otoka Hvara, Hrvatska (Oxford: BAR International Series 660, 1997), 109-110; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no.20.
properties.Comments: A combined cargo of stone blocks and pottery.
properties.Marble type: About 10 half-finished stone blocks, one of them dark greenish granite, while others are of limestone.
properties.Other cargo: About 2,500 pieces of various  pottery, half are Eastern Sigillata B (plates and platters) many with stamps, potter Sporos's amongst them. The rest was eastern coarse ware with about 10 forms of mugs, jugs, dishes, pots, plates, pans etc.
properties.Hull remains: Timber and nails.

properties.Name: Parzanj
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 53; M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: A completely looted wreck of mainly Spanish amphorae.
properties.Other cargo: Mortaria.
properties.Ship equipment: A large amount of ballast stones indicate that the ship was partially empty when it sank.

properties.Name: Goica/Gojca Islet
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 11
properties.Comments: Although other amphorae (Dr 2-4 and Dr 1) and remains of a lead bilge pump are mentioned by other sources, this may be unreliable information. NB Date change since Parker
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Three mugs of Izmetiste type are mentioned in the initial report of 1974.

properties.Name: Cavalaire 1
properties.Reference: M. Dalhaye, Bilan Scientifique 1994, 50;  Bilan Scientifique 1995, 54-56; Bilan Scientifique 1996, 100-101
properties.Comments: An interesting ship in that its construction seems to have originated from the Bay of Biscay/Atlantic style of ship building. It was carrying weapons.
properties.Other cargo: A huge amount of weapons - at least 8 cannons, projectile weapons, crossbow parts, lance tips.
properties.Hull remains: Extremely well preserved - Bay of Biscay style of ship building (clinker style) - position of the cabin, the type of nailing etc.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Whale bones - the remains of a whale hunt or simply bones that were used as tools?
properties.Ship equipment: All sorts of pulleys.

properties.Name: Pelegrin (cape)
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 54
properties.Comments: A totally looted site of amphorae and pottery.
properties.Other cargo: ECW -like pottery.

properties.Name: Port Miou C
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 52; Bilan Scientifique 2001, 62        http://piccard.esil.univmed.fr/venus/external/webMarseille/pres2.php?language=en
properties.Comments: The site comprises a mound 24 x 12m, with at least of two layers of amphorae. The cargo is composed of almost 1500 or 2000 visible amphorae and there may be a total of 3000 or 3500.

properties.Name: Calanque d'En Vau 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 52.
properties.Comments: A wreck of tegulae and imbrices.
properties.Other cargo: Tegulae and imbrices
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Dressel 2-4 amphorae.

properties.Name: Cap Camarat 2
properties.Reference: M.-B. Carre, Bilan scientifique 1992, 50-1; Bilan Scientifique1993, 49, Bilan Scientifique 1994, 50-51.
properties.Comments: A cargo of oil amphorae.
properties.Other cargo: Red slip Arretine ware. Eastern sigillata A.
properties.Hull remains: Very well preserved section of the hull. Parts of the cabin.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Tableware and metal tools ( 2 bronze 'simpula', a spatula , tweezers and a curette that may be medical impements; a lamp; a fibula decorated with a bird's head. A box filled with a concretion of coins and fish hooks. A touchstone.
properties.Ship equipment: Pipe from the bilge pump.

properties.Name: Jarre-Ecueil de Miet 4
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2001, 59-60; Bilan Scientifique 2002, 62.
properties.Comments: Also known originally as Jarre 4.
properties.Hull remains: 30 concretions of nails, a small portion of the hull on which were 3 iron ingots
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Coarseware

properties.Name: Ecueil de Miet 3
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 51; L. Long, P. Pomey and J-C Souriseau, Les Etrusques en Mer (2000)
properties.Comments: Shattered remains of Etruscan amphorae from a site with at least 3 other wrecks.

properties.Name: Port-Miou (Port Miou B)
properties.Reference: C. Dovis, Bilan Scientifique 1992, 46
properties.Comments: A late C4th to early C5th AD wreck with a cargo of African amphorae and ceramics.
properties.Other cargo: Sigillata D or African redslip, Hayes 81 B and 67 B 33.

properties.Name: Sud Gracieuse
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2000, 59-60.

properties.Name: Tiboulen de Maire 1
properties.Reference: S. Ximenes and M. Moerman, Bilan Scientifique 1999, 48; Bilan Scientifique 2000, 62; 2001, 59; Bilan Scientifique 2002, 6; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 81; Bilan Scientifique 2004, 72; Bilan Scientifique 2005. 75.
properties.Comments: A cargo of Spanish and Gauloise amphorae from a ship measuring about 30m.
properties.Hull remains: At least 2.1m x 1.35m is preserved with part of the keel and 6 frames. The ship is estimated to have been 30 m long and 12m wide.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Pottery including jugs, amphorettes and an oil lamp.

properties.Name: Pampelonne
properties.Reference: M. Bonifay et al, in L. Rivet and M. Sciallano (eds). Vivre, Produire et Echanger: Reflets Mediterraneans. Melanges offerts a Bernard Liou (2002), 196-97
properties.Comments: A principal cargo of African amphorae of which 46 were brought to the surface.

properties.Name: Les Basses du Can
properties.Comments: An area 80 x 90m was assessed by a single-seat submarine in 1987.

properties.Name: Le Grand Souffre
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 49
properties.Comments: A looted site of a shipwreck of Dr 1B amphorae.
properties.Hull remains: A few fragments of wood and a small piece of lead sheathing
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Coarseware fragments

properties.Name: Calanque de l'Ane
properties.Reference: S. Ximenes and M. Moerman, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 12 (1994), 95-112; Bilan Scientifique 1997, 49-50; Bilan Scientifique 1998, 39; Archaeonautica 14, (1998), 299-302
properties.Comments: A very robust ship, about 25m x 6m, carrying a cargo of tiles.
properties.Other cargo: A cargo of tiles, tegulae and imbrices, still in rows.
properties.Hull remains: Well preserved section of 13.4m of robust construction. A massive mast step sits on 2 lateral keelsons; it is supported on both sides of the mast-step cavity by 2 pieces of buttressing with a triangular profile, elements never seen before on an ancient wreck. These pieces rest on the lateral keelsons and are nailed at their ends to the frames. A bronze sestertius of Domitian was found in the mast-step.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Ceramics: plates, jugs, bowls, several terra sigillata bowls, oil lamps, some amphorae (Dr 20 and Gauloise 4) and glass containers. A piece of leather possibly from a sling. A sestertius of Titus.

properties.Name: Agde B
properties.Reference: Bouscaras, 1953, 1954, 1962: 11 and fig.5, 1974; Jannoray, 1954: 413; Gallet de Santerre, 1961; Carrazé, 1970d; cf. Clavel, 1970:409 ff.
properties.Comments: A 'quantity' of amphorae  but reports disagree as to their form which suggests that several wrecks lie on top of each other cf. Marzamemi B, D, G and H although there is no direct evidence to confirm this.
properties.Other cargo: Campanian B pottery.
properties.Hull remains: Traces of timbers

properties.Name: Balise de Rabiou
properties.Reference: B. Dangreaux,  Bilan Scientifique 1993, 50; A. and P. Joncheray,Bilan Scientifique 2001, 78-79; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 91-92; Bilan Scientifique 2004, 83; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 80-81.
properties.Comments: A cargo of amphorae from a small local ship.
properties.Hull remains: Some well preserved sections including the keel, the mast-step  and about 40 frames and interestingly, some pieces of leather.
properties.Ship equipment: Anchor parts

properties.Name: Les Catalans 2
properties.Reference: L. Long and A. Hermary, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 16 (2007), 117-130
properties.Comments: A small bronze statue, fragments of 2 marble statues and a great number of unfinished architectural pieces were found 2001-2004. They may come from one wreck.
properties.Marble type: The remains of 2 white marble statues.  One of the statues (46cm high) ressembles an Apollo although there is no head, datable to mid C1st AD, whilst the other is simply part of a female foot with a sandal. A great number of unfinished architectural pieces - columns, architraves, capitals, slabs - may or may not be from the same wreck.
properties.Other cargo: The small bronze statue represents Apollo as well and is 12cm high, found 138m away from the marble statues. It is of mediocre quality and is datable to the Roman Imperial period.

properties.Name: Les Riches Dunes 5
properties.Reference: M.- P. Jézégou, Bilan scientifique du Département des recherches archéologiques sous-marines (2002), p. 47;  M.- P. Jézégou and H. Bernard, Bilan scientifique du Département des recherches archéologiques sous-marines (2003), 41and 52-55.
properties.Comments: Another wreck between Sete and Marseillan, found 30m from the 2 bronze statues (Les Riches Dunes 4), with a cargo of marble.
properties.Marble type: A partially worked block of Luna marble 2m x 1m x 0.4m = 3.3 tons buried in sediment.Twenty-one plaques of grey marble; all are broken, but polished on both sides,  the largest one measures 28cm x 20cm apart from a triangular one of 44.2cm x 55.5cm. Small white column 50.4cm long.An Ionic white marble base of plinth and drum in perfect condition.
properties.Other cargo: The head of an ibis made of lead 12.5cm long. These finds suggest the ship was carrying the property of a private collector.
properties.Hull remains: Nails still in alignment give an idea of the hull shape. Lead sheathing.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A millstone.
properties.Ship equipment: A pipe from the pump, tiles from the roof of the cabin.

properties.Name: Tour du Castellas 1
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2003, 41-42
properties.Comments: Another of the many ancient wrecks between Sete and Cap d'Agde.
properties.Other cargo: A bronze Etruscan tripod dated to the beginning of the C5th BC.
properties.Hull remains: Bronze nails.
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock and a small iron anchor

properties.Name: Les Riches Dunes 4
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2002, 47; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 42-46; Bilan Scientifique 2004, 42-43.
properties.Comments: A storm shifted sand that exposed 2 Roman statues lying 25om off the coast.
properties.Other cargo: Two bronze statues: the first is of a young naked child, 65cm high, possibly Eros, datable to C1st BC- AD. The second is also of a child, in a short tunic, 80cm high and very well preserved, datable to the same era. They are both probablly from Campania and may have belonged to an Italian moving to Gaul (?). A mosaic  emblema measuring 48 x 49cm representing the judgement of Marsyas on a base of travertine.
properties.Hull remains: Copper nails, lead sheathing.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Various ceramics including fragments of terra sigillatta produced between 30 and 10 BC
properties.Ship equipment: An iron anchor, a lead pipe and bronze rings probably from a bilge pump.

properties.Name: Les Riches Dunes 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2003, 40
properties.Other cargo: 17 lead ingots.

properties.Name: Les Riches Dunes 6
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2003, 41

properties.Name: Les Tambours
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2000, 53-54
properties.Comments: Dispersed over an area 20m x 6m were 16 stone column drums.
properties.Marble type: Sixteen drums measuring between 0.5 and 0.8m high with traces of inscriptions, possibly from Les Lens

properties.Name: Bonnieu 5
properties.Reference: S. Gadal, Bilan Scientifique 1994, 36
properties.Comments: A small cargo of limestone blocks.
properties.Marble type: Three rows of 57 finished limestone blocks

properties.Name: Bonnieu 3
properties.Reference: B. Maillet, Bilan Scientifique 1993, 34; Bilan Scientifique 1997, 49; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 79.
properties.Comments: A much looted C5th BC shipwreck.
properties.Other cargo: Millstones from Marseilles.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: The bottom of an Attic cup

properties.Name: Les Aresquiers 2
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 33
properties.Comments: A possible wreck a mile and a half off the coast of Frontignan.

properties.Name: Dramont A
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1998, 52
properties.Marble type: Stone blocks measuring 4 x 1 x 1m
properties.Hull remains: Well preserved 17m x 4-8m  portside section.

properties.Name: Dramont C
properties.Reference: J.-P. Joncheray, Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 12 (1994), 5-51; Bilan Scienifique 1998, 52
properties.Comments: A small coastal boat, 12-14m long, that was carrying amphorae, ceramics and iron bars.
properties.Other cargo: Iron bars and blocks of resin; 3 millstones. Numerous ceramics, ollae, olpes, jars, plates, cups and some copper tableware.
properties.Hull remains: A 6m x 1.6m section was preserved and some ligature attachments were seen, cf Cap Bear 3 wreck
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Stone slabs interpreted by J. P. Joncheray as a work bench for cutting out amphora stoppers.
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast of limestone blocks. Four different anchors, 3 of which had lead stocks.

properties.Name: Dramont I
properties.Reference: A. Lopez, Bilan Scientifique 1991, 52-53; Bilan Scientifique 1993, 51; A. Joncheray and J.-P. Joncheray, Cahiers d' archéologie subaquatique13 (1997), 165-195; A. Joncheray, in E. Rieth (ed.), Méditerranée antique (1998), 139-156.
properties.Comments: A navis lapidaria whose 3 remaining blocks of marble were curiously not covering the hull which was found a few metres away.
properties.Marble type: In an area of 500m sq, three blocks of africano marble were found (2.2m x 1m x 1m; 3.8m x 0.95m x 0.8m; 2.68m x 1.1m x 1m). A total weight of 23 tons.
properties.Other cargo: A complementary cargo of polished (pumice) stones, equivalent to 500 litres. Several hundred kilos of corundum, a very hard and heavy mineral probably from the island of Naxos.
properties.Hull remains: On the eastern side is a large fragment of the hull, more than 8m long of more than thirty frames and seven strakes, two of which are larch. On the other side are two fragments of the keel and some strakes.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Statuette (or mirror handle?) in bronze of a cobra. A scrolled oil lamp. Already broken fragments of Dr. 2-4, Dr.7-11 and Dr. 20 amphorae. A very crumpled bronze urn.
properties.Ship equipment: A piece of lead piping.

properties.Name: Conque des Salins
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 35-38
properties.Comments: A 15m hull in very good condition, the shipw as probably only used within the Etang for trading or unloading from larger ships.
properties.Hull remains: A section 7.7m long and 2.2 m wide was preserved of this flat-bottomed boat showing  the keel, frames etc.

properties.Name: Les Mouettes
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1998,  27; Bilan Scientifique 1999, 33
properties.Comments: A wreck that has not been excavated although many objects have come to light from the site at the entrance to the port of Frontignan.
properties.Other cargo: Tiles, copper ingots and lead ingots some of which are stamped M AURELI; a bronze tripod.
properties.Hull remains: Copper nails
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Bronze and silver coins (one of Marcus Aurelius); a bronze ax head and  bronze scales; an oil lamp and part of a pot representing the head of a ram.
properties.Ship equipment: A sounding weight, rings associated with the rigging and 2 iron anchors

properties.Name: Chretienne D
properties.Reference: J-P. Joncheray, Bilan Scientifique 1994, 54; Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 13 (1997), 121-135
properties.Comments: Over 2,400 amphora sherds have been identified, 58% of which are Amalgro C and 17% are Dr 23, thus giving an estimated total of 500 amphorae.
properties.Ship equipment: At least 2 iron anchors

properties.Name: Saintes Maries-de-la-mer 21
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan scientifique du Département des recherches archéologiques sous-marines (1999), 41-43.
properties.Marble type: Seven blocks of Luna marble, two of which are completely buried in sediment. The heaviest load of the three marble wrecks at Saintes Marie.

properties.Name: Saintes Maries-de-la-mer 22
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan scientifique du Département des recherches archéologiques sous-marines (1999), 41-43.
properties.Comments: A few fragments of Dr. 20 date the wreck.
properties.Marble type: Six or seven blocks of Luna marble over an area 12m long, parallel to the beach. Two of the blocks are half cylindrical, i.e. part columns, 2.1m long. Three others are rectangular.

properties.Name: Chretienne M
properties.Reference: A. and J.-P. Joncheray, Bilan Scientifique 1994, 53, Bilan Scientifique 1997, 76-77; Cahiers d'Archeologie Subaquatique 14 (2002) 57-130

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-mer 18
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan Scientifique 1999, 41-43; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 54-55
properties.Comments: A small cargo of Luna marble.
properties.Marble type: Seven blocks of Luna marble in disorder over an area 8m long. The main block measures 2.8m x 1.1m, the others are smaller (1.4m x 1.7m, 1.8m x 1.5m etc).

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 19
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2000, 57-58; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 64
properties.Comments: A cargo of Dr 30 amphorae from Mauretania.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-mer 11
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1998, 36
properties.Other cargo: Iron ingots amalgamated with fragments of amphorae.
properties.Hull remains: Some frames
properties.Ship equipment: An iron anchor.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-mer 13
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1998, 36
properties.Comments: Another shipwreck of iron ingots.
properties.Other cargo: Iron ingots.
properties.Hull remains: Fragments of wood.
properties.Ship equipment: An iron anchor was found 20m away

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-mer 23
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2001, 50; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 65
properties.Comments: Another wreck of iron ingots
properties.Other cargo: Iron ingots in mass concretions, 3m x 2m.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A basket/ container of small iron nails.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 3
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan Scientifique 1995, 42; Bilan Scientifique 1996, 73-74,
properties.Other cargo: Concretions of iron bars.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A fragment of a sigillata  from Southern Gaul, Dragendorff 15a1.
properties.Ship equipment: An iron anchor

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 24
properties.Reference: L. Long et al, Bilan Scientifique 2002, 53-54; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 66-71.
properties.Comments: Another wreck of iron bars and ingots from a ship 20-25m long.
properties.Other cargo: Large iron bars weighing between 23 and 33kg.
properties.Hull remains: Fairly well preserved
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Several bronze objects including a lantern. Human remains including a jaw

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 2
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan Scientifique 1995, 40-41; Bilan Scientifique 1996, 73; Bilan Scientifique 1997, 65-68; Liou 2000, 1070 no. 39; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 65; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 49.
properties.Comments: A cargo of iron ingots and bars seen as a number of concretions over a 15m long site.
properties.Other cargo: Iron ingots and 146 bars some of which are very well preserved with stamps EROTIS and LEPIDI, plus symbols of anchors and other unidentifiable oval shapes. Some measure as long as 123cm and weigh 6.5kg. The total number may have been as high as 3000 to 4000.
properties.Hull remains: Partially preserved under the concretions along with some branches of grapevines used as protection for the cargo, the ship is estimated to have been 15-20m long.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 10
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan Scientifique, 1996, 75; Bilan Scientifique 1997, 44-45; Bilan Scientifique 1998, 35; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 51.
properties.Comments: Another wreck of iron ingots discovered in 1996.
properties.Other cargo: A concretion 8m long of iron ingots with illegible stamps.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 8
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan Scientifique 1996, 75
properties.Comments: Another wreck of iron ingots.
properties.Other cargo: Twenty concretions of iron ingots.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-mer 27
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2005, 51
properties.Comments: The eleventh shipwreck or iron ingots discovered in the Camargues area.
properties.Other cargo: Iron ingots and bars.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A basket/ container of small iron nails.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 4
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2001, 51-52; Bilan Scientifique 2002, 60-64; Bilan Scientifique 2003, 59-64; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 55.
properties.Comments: A cargo of bronze objects.
properties.Other cargo: A large number of bronze objects - tableware, furniture pieces, jewellery and a statuette possibly of Mercury. Bronze scales, measuring 26cm and engraved with numbers I-VII on one side, with hooks decorated as ducks' heads; a few other bronze decoration fragments including part of a 'simplum' and a hinged bronze lid decorated with a dolphin.

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer 25
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2003, 65-66; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 48
properties.Comments: Another wreck of iron ingots.
properties.Other cargo: About 50 tons of iron bars and ingots in concretion.
properties.Ship equipment: A stockless lead anchor, 2.65m long, and an iron anchor

properties.Name: Saintes-Maries-de-la-mer 9
properties.Reference: L. Long, Bilan Scientifique 1996, 75; Bilan Scientifique 1998, 34-35; Bilan Scientifique, 2002, 43; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 50-51
properties.Comments: Another wreck of iron ingots.
properties.Other cargo: Hundreds of iron ingots of differing sizes in 4 rows and at least 2 layers in concreted masses, some stamped. A piece of ceramic?
properties.Hull remains: A few planks, copper nails.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A Mayence type sword which dates the wreck to C1st AD.

properties.Name: Mlin
properties.Reference: D. Vrsalović, Istraživanja i Zaštita Podmorških Arheoloskih Spomenika u S.R. Hrvatskoj (1974), 25; D. Vrsalović, PhD thesis (unpublished, 1979), 217-18; N. Cambi, Amphores Romaines, MEFRA 114 (1989), 323-5; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 45.
properties.Comments: A heavily looted mixed cargo of Greek amphorae - Rhodian in two sizes, smaller Rhodian with ribbed belly, Greek variant of Dr. 2-4, Cnidian in two sizes, possibly Dr. 28 and at least three other unidentified forms.
properties.Hull remains: Remains of the hull.
properties.Ship equipment: Two lead anchor stocks, though possibly not from this site.

properties.Name: Plage Beauregard
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 34; Bilan Scientifique 2000, 48
properties.Comments: An area 150m long of concreted amphora fragments found 250m from the coast. It is uncertain whether this is a homogenous wreck site or simply spillage from the nearby Riches Dunes 2 and Beausejour wrecks.
properties.Hull remains: A piece of lead sheathing showed traces of nails.

properties.Name: Saint Honorat
properties.Comments: Cargo composed entirely of Dr  20. Cargo looted.
properties.Hull remains: None.

properties.Name: La Tradelière
properties.Reference: P. Fiori, Cahiers d’Archéologie Subaquatique 1 (1972), 115-17, IJNA 3 (1974), 328-9; B. Liou Gallia 31 (1973), 603-4; J-P. Joncheray, IJNA 5 (1976), 259-60; A. Hesnard, MEFRA 89 (1977), 163; Hesnard et al., Archaeonautica 8 (1988), 55-6; P. Pomey et al., Gallia Informations 1 (1989), 48-9; Parker (1992), 1174; P. Pomey and F. Guibal, Bilan scientifique du Département des recherches archéologiques sous-marines (1999), 66-67.
properties.Comments: A tumulus of twelve types of amphorae (altogether 300-400), the top two layers of which were Rhodian and Chian, Dr. 2-4 (probably Coan), making up 50% of the cargo and Dr. 6.
properties.Other cargo: Tens of thousands of hazelnuts, which formed a layer up to a metre thick. Pottery including Pompeian red plates, rimless platters, fine-wall goblets and two-handled and four-handled cups, as well as two pieces of eastern pottery. Glass cups, stacked in piles of 8 or 10, in six different colours.
properties.Hull remains: A well preserved hull 25m longand 6m wide with a single layer of planking. Portions of the keel, the stempost, strakes, half frames and ribs - typical shell-first construction.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A 'guttus' or flask with one handle and a relief head of an antelope forming the spout. Some miniature amphorae, possibly a merchant's samples(?).
properties.Ship equipment: Some discs and a bearing from the pump.

properties.Name: Cape Gradina
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000) no. 13
properties.Comments: A possible shipwreck or simply solitary amphora finds.

properties.Name: Les Pierres
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 1999, 33; Bilan Scientifique 2001, 47
properties.Comments: A presumed cargo of stone.
properties.Other cargo: 75 blocks of stone from Bois des Lens, north-west of Nimes, including 7 columns and capitals. The blocks were still lying in alignment and were rectangular; the dimensions varied between 0.7 0.75 x 0.6m and 2.85 x 0.6 x0.7m. This type of stone was popular for its similar look to marble.

properties.Name: Jaz, islet
properties.Reference: M. Jurisić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 23
properties.Comments: A possible shipwreck based on 2 amphorae and fragments and some corroded iron.
properties.Ship equipment: Some corrided iron, possibly an anchor.

properties.Name: Maguelone
properties.Reference: Bilan Scientifique 2003, 56; Bilan Scientifique 2005, 39.
properties.Other cargo: 12 copper ingots and an iron bar stamped with HAEDI cf Saintes-Maries-de-la-mer 2.
properties.Ship equipment: An iron anchor

properties.Name: Secche della Meloria
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana, 2002, p. 460; S. Bargagliotti et al, Atti del Convegno Nazionale di Archeologia Subacquea. Anzio 1996, (1997), 43-53.
properties.Comments: Could be two wrecks, but one is described as being a group of ceramic blocks and concreted amphorae.
properties.Other cargo: Black-glazed pottery.

properties.Name: Cap Gros C
properties.Reference: B. Gauthier, Bilan Scientifique 1992, 55; Bilan Scientifique 1995, 63
properties.Comments: A small cargo of amphorae from the Adriatic, unusual to find this far west.
properties.Ship equipment: Three stockless lead anchors, an iron anchor and a lead ring

properties.Name: Gusteranski
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000) no. 17
properties.Comments: A heavily looted cargo of amphorae and Pompeian red ware.
properties.Other cargo: South Italian Pompeian ware consisting of 'orlo bifido' bowls, with plates/lids and standard Pompeian red plates, which were only 15% of the total of 50 brought to the surface.

properties.Name: Koromasna  Cove
properties.Reference: J. Mesić, Obavijesti HAD-a XXX1/2 (1999), 76; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 30; M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: Intact cargo of Greek amphorae, Cretan AC4 and Aegean ER1. More than 100 each of AC4 and ER1 amphorae now preserved under an iron cage.

properties.Name: Tijascica
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 78
properties.Comments: Only piles of fragments remain from this amphorae wreck.
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock and an iron anchor stock were found nearby.

properties.Name: Plavac A
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 56; M . Jurisic in D. Davison, V. Gaffney and E. Martin (eds.) BAR 2006, 175-192
properties.Comments: An eastern cargo of amphorae in a fairly well preserved wreck.
properties.Hull remains: Quite well preserved
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: ECW mugs, profiled plates, dishes with lids and trefoil mouth jugs; cups and 2-handled saucers from Pergamom, Arretine Conspectus R2 form, a TS plate with the stamp TETTI and parts of 2 oil lamps.
properties.Ship equipment: Two iron anchors, the lead parts of a bilge pump, the remains of a pulley and a lead sounding weight.

properties.Name: Marinieres I
properties.Reference: M. Daeffler, Bilan Scientifique 1997, 78.
properties.Comments: Dated by dendrachronology. No cargo.
properties.Hull remains: A large section of the hull, 18 x 8.7m, is well preserved resting on its side.

properties.Name: Pisa A
properties.Reference:
S. Bruni (ed.), Le Navi Antichi di Pisa: ad un Anno dall'Inizio delle Ricerche (2000);  G. Belluomini et al, Science and Technology for Cultural Heritage 11 (2002); M. properties.Hull remains: Unfortunately split into 2 during the construction works, this ship is estimated to have been 30m in length
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Ceramics including African terra sigillata.

properties.Comments: One of nineteen well-preserved ancient ships found during construction work in San Rossore railway station, Pisa. A transport ship of medium dimensions, recovered tilted on its side. Adriatic and Baetican amphorae had been reused to carry fruit, nuts and salted fish as well as augitic sand of Latium or Campania origin. It is still uncertain what the real purpose was of such sand. The skeletons of a 40-45 year-old man and a dog were also found.
properties.Hull remains: Enough remains were preserved to show that the ship was 4m wide.
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast stones, formed from rounded off blocks of various sizes, from Campania; stowage material found between the amphorae from the Neapolitan area.

properties.Name: Pisa C
properties.Reference:
S. Bruni (ed.), Le Navi Antichi di Pisa: ad un Anno dall'Inizio delle Ricerche (2000);  G. Belluomini et al, Science and Technology for Cultural Heritage 11 (2002); M. Pecchioni et al, Arcaeometry 49 (2007), 1-22                            http://www.navipisa.it/scavo_naveC_nave.htm
http://www.mclink.it/assoc/assonet/arcart/rosso2.htm
properties.Comments: One of nineteen well-preserved ancient ships found during construction work in San Rossore railway station, Pisa. This large fluvial boat, 14m long, has been recovered moored to a pole with a large cable: the boat is still in an optimal state of conservation.
properties.Hull remains: The majority of the structural elements are intact (keel, keelson, frame, mast partners and step, top of bulwarks, prow bollards and six rowing benches set at regular intervals). All around, in correspondence to the benches, are conserved the holes for the oars, into which are series of small nails in order to fix the leather. White and red paint can still be seen on the external planks above the waterline. A Greek inscription, ALKDO, can be read on the 1st rowing bench.

properties.Name: Pisa D
properties.Reference: S. Bruni (ed.), Le Navi Antichi di Pisa: ad un Anno dall'Inizio delle Ricerche (2000);  G. Belluomini et al, Science and Technology for Cultural Heritage 11 (2002); M. properties.Comments: One of nineteen well-preserved ancient ships found during construction work in San Rossore railway station, Pisa. This is the draft of a large river boat, 14m long and 6m wide.  It has been recovered turned upside down and quite completely lacking its hull; some parts, like the keel, were perhaps cut off in ancient time.
properties.Hull remains: Some structures of this upside down river boat survive.
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast stones.

properties.Comments: One of nineteen well-preserved ancient ships found during construction work in San Rossore railway station, Pisa. This ship is lying on its side and had been transporting dolia and Dr 2-4 amphorae.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A terracotta phallus which suggests that the Priapus deity was seen as an icon of maritime activity as well as a garden fertility god.
properties.Ship equipment: A large wooden anchor.

properties.Hull remains: A slim fluvial 9m long and only 1m wide, a 'lintres' type of Roman ship. Made of oak and small alder sections.

properties.Name: Pisa I
properties.Reference: S. Bruni (ed.), Le Navi Antichi di Pisa: ad un Anno dall'Inizio delle Ricerche (2000);  G. Belluomini et al, Science and Technology for Cultural Heritage 11 (2002); M. properties.Comments: One of nineteen well-preserved ancient ships found during construction work in San Rossore railway station, Pisa. This river boat was carrying African amphorae, presumably unloading them from a much larger ship.
properties.Hull remains: A river boat 12m x 2.5m, Roman 'lintres' type. Mortise and tenon construction with iron nails.

properties.Name: Pisa Hellenistic ship
properties.Reference: S. Bruni (ed.), Le Navi Antichi di Pisa: ad un Anno dall'Inizio delle Ricerche (2000);  G. Belluomini et al, Science and Technology for Cultural Heritage 11 (2002); M. Colombini et al, Archaeolmetry 45 (2003), 659-674; A. Camilli, Archaeologia Maritima Mediterranea 1 (2004), 53-75; E. Pecchioni et al, Arcaeometry 49 (2007), 1-22                           http://www.cantierenavipisa.it/Scavo_NaveEllenistica.html
properties.Comments: One of nineteen well-preserved ancient ships found during construction work in San Rossore railway station, Pisa. A medium-sized merchant ship from Spain, with an estimated half of its cargo still on board. It had broken up as a result of a violent crash against the quayside, probably caused by a huge flood.
properties.Hull remains: A few remains, indicating medium-sized vessel.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Ceramics including numerous kalathoi from southern Spain. An Iberian area origin is also given to the thymiateria, while some unguentari  seem of a massaliota production and one, of remarkable dimensions, seems to have been produced in Ampurias. Bones including the front shoulders of a pig were also found.
properties.Ship equipment: Ballast stones.

properties.Name: Martinska

properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck of flat-bottomed amphorae.

properties.Comments: Discovered in 2003 by carabinieri divers, the wreck site measures approximately 20m x 10m. The ship could carry about 3000 amphorae (about 150 tons). Just a few amphorae of the cargo have been stolen by souvenir hunters.

properties.Comments: A cargo of North Italian amphorae which probably numbered over 1700 originally, before the site was looted.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: Three North Italian lamps, a red Pompeian plate, an ESB Hayes 80 plate, 3 ESW specimens, a few North Italian(?) glass vessels, south italian (?) bronze service patera-jug and a sestertius of Trajan.

properties.Name: Margarina Point
properties.Region: near Susak Island, NW of Zadar
properties.Reference: D. Vrsalović, Istraživanja i Zaštita Podmorških Arheoloskih Spomenika u S.R. Hrvatskoj (1974), 53 and 240; M. Jurišić, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no.43.
properties.Comments: A cargo of unfinished blocks of stone and marble columns, the largest such cargo in the eastern Adriatic.
properties.Marble type: Several unfinished blocks and  20 worked white marble columns.
properties.Other cargo: Flat roof tiles and curved roof tiles.

properties.Name: Vele Orjule/Lussino
properties.Reference:

http://www.mclink.it/assoc/assonet/arcart/lussino.htm
properties.Comments: A solitary statue was discovered in several pieces in 1997 and has now been fully restored.
properties.Other cargo: A life-size bronze statue of 'Apoxyomenos' was found as a solitary find. Supposedly a Hellenistic or Roman copy of the famous Greek C4th original. Dated by organic material found inside the statue.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A few sherds of Lam. 2 and two solitary Forl. type amphorae found at a distance.
properties.Ship equipment: A lead anchor stock nearby and another smaller one at a distance.

properties.Comments: A cargo of roof tiles.

properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 74

properties.Name: Kvarner Gulf
properties.Reference: Plongées 76, xvi; Parker (1992), 561.

properties.Name: Čavlena
properties.Reference: D. Vrsalović, Istraživanja i Zaštita Podmorških Arheoloskih Spomenika u S.R. Hrvatskoj (1974), 53 and 240; Parker (1992), 288.
properties.Marble type: Marble ‘elaborated’ columns and other stones.

properties.Name: Pakleni Cape
properties.Reference: M. Jurisic, Ancient Shipwrecks of the Adriatic (2000), no. 52
properties.Comments: A probable shipwreck from a much looted site of amphorae.

properties.Name: Caorle
properties.Reference: C. Beltrame, Vita di Bordo in Eta Romana 2002, 456; G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 181.         http://www.comune.caorle.ve.it/storia_e_cultura/archeologia.php
properties.Comments: Discovered in 1992 in international waters and seen through videos, the site appears to be a classic ellipsoidal tumulus of amphorae covered by a layer of concretion 30cm thick. The wreck had already been damaged by fishing boats, but is now protected and "sealed". The ship may have been 23m long and 9m wide.
properties.Hull remains: Good condition.

properties.Name: Grado (Julia Felix)
properties.Reference: S. Picozzi Subacqueo 16 (1988) 46-50; R. Auriemma, MEFRA 112 (2000), 27-51; C. Beltrame and D. Gaddi, IJNA 34 (2005), 79-87; G. Lattanzi, Navi e Citta Sommerse (2007), 184-91; C. Beltrame, IJNA 36 (2007)138-147; JP Oleson and R. Stein, IJNA 36 (2007), 415-416; P. Dell'Amico, Archaeologia Maritima Mediterranea 7 (2010).                                               http://www.archeosub.it/news1999/news9911.htm#felix2                                                                                                                                       http://www.archeosub.it/news2000/news0007.htm
properties.Comments: At least one layer of several types including Africano I, Tripolitanian, Coan, Dr.5 and Kapitän 1. They held garum and small pieces of fish that were perfectly preserved. Small amphorae of North-east Italy. It seems that all of the amphorae were being re-used to carry fish products. At least 600 in total, estimated 23-25 tons.
properties.Other cargo: Bronze stands with lions’ paws and acanthus decoration. Glass, much of it waste glass, packed in a barrel which had disintegrated; some square bottles with the base mark C SALVI GRATI.
properties.Hull remains: The ship is estimated 18m x 5m, lead sheathed and some of the frames are squared off. The right side of the ship is completely preserved and shows a mortise and tenon construction, with all the frames built from pine, while planking is either of pine or elm. Some strakes, of Alpine larch, are a repair made by patch-tenons. Presumably a short-haul trade ship? A bronze coin was found in the mast-step.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A dolium, common and African pottery. A box of fishing hooks. Some games including a die. Bronze figurine of Neptune.
properties.Ship equipment: A bronze steelyard-weight in the form of Minerva and a conical sounding lead. Many wooden elements of the rigging have been preserved including a large block with six pulleys and a bilge pump that are unique, as well as3 wooden toggles. An iron anchor.

properties.Name: Grado (2000)
properties.Reference: http://www.archeosub.it/news2000/news0007.htm
properties.Comments: Found near the other Grado wreck, the wreck was carrying Sicilian and central Italian amphorae.
properties.Shipboard paraphernalia: A Graeco-Italic amphora
properties.Ship equipment: Two lead anchor stocks of 150kg.

properties.Name: Antikythera
properties.Comments: One of the earliest wrwcks to be excavated in 1900. Rhodian, Coan and Lamboglia 2 amphorae were found, about half of which remain on the seabed. Between 70 and 80 amphorae in total. Works of art, pottery and glass ware also formed part of the wreck.
properties.Other cargo: 36 marble statues, many of which are copies of bronze originals that are unknown. Fragments of more statues. Contemporary works of art and old masters from C 4th-2nd BC, including the bronze Antikythera Youth, a bearded head, a pair of statuettes and a bronze bed. A large amount of fine and coarse pottery. A dozen glass vessels, possibly Alexandrian? Piles of coins from Pergamum 88-86 BC and gold bars. A necklace, a ring and other jewellery. Ingots and lead items. An astronomical computer by which the wreck is dated.

properties.Name: Alexandria B
properties.Comments: Probably Dr. 6 amphorae. Large quantities.
